reviewText:
Early Access Review

A note on the negative comments: I've read through the negs on the reviews and in 99% of cases, the problem is easily resolved if you check the forums on the stonehearth webpage. Usually the problems are solved with a reboot of the game due to errors while the game engine is still in developement.

I have almost 900 hours on this game. Already for more fun than most AAA titles with far better replayability. Obviously it's an alpha so there are bugs but I've never seen a company so dedicated to getting the bugs squished as quickly as possible. I really can't give this game a high enough rating and it just continues to get better with every release. It is already well worth the money and it's a game that every member of the family can play.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I have played Stonehearth for 341 hours and have enjoyed playing through the developing stages. The game is becoming more polished and seems to be headed in a positive direction. I would recommend this to someone who enjoys a sandbox building and crafting games where they can design towns and villages with a little bit of hostile goblins thrown in to the mix.

I do not recommend this yet for someone that is expecting a finished polished product or get upset when an error message pops up.

The Good
- I find the game extremely fun to play with the ability to design your own houses and structures.
- The pace of the game is relaxing and the music is very soothing.
- The Heathing are amusing as they try to carry out your commands
- There are more creatures to worry about now as Giant Zombie, Stone Golems, Eants, and what looks like a mutant alligator roam the land. Undead Villages complete with crazed necromancers pop up and flood the night with undead critters.
- The ability to create Mods will mean continued content. I hope that this also continues to develop end game content.
- Weekly twitch feed keep you updated on developments and lets you give feed back to the developers.

The Bad
- There are still errors when trying to build structures, and it takes a while to learn what works and what does not. It seems the building logic really wants you to lay down your design in a certain way. I watched a twitch feed were the designer was working on this to allow the engine to be more flexible.
- The Hearthling become idler as your town, village, Kingdom expands. I am unsure if this is caused by distance, memory issues or pathing (although sometime it’s because I ran out of wood). The developers have work hard and these issues have improved greatly since I started playing it. (I still have to chop my own wood of course)
- The end game is not there yet.  There is a basic scenario evolving Blood thirsty goblins which ends after 4 or 5 encounters.  Following that you only have to fend off random creatures once or twice a day.

I will continue to play and follow this game as it develops.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Dude. DUDE. Look at this.
It's an Early Access game... and they're WORKING ON IT.

I've been playing Stonehearth on and off for a while, the interest spikes obviously coinciding with updates, and I am glad to say this game does not have potential. It has promise. Because a promise is something you actually follow through on.

Like everyone else is saying, it is by no means complete. Think about it: it's a sandbox game and they only just put the zombies and water in. How complete is that to you?

But it all works, more or less. More THAN less. There are peculiarities, certainly - when I tell you tiny voxel people to pick berries, I mean I want you to TAKE those berries back to town - but it doesn't hiccup too often. And there have been some interesting hiccups. The biggest one, which involved two separate timers ingame and their misbehavior, the devs actually detailed in a blog post.

Which brings me to the dev team, Radiant. These people talk with their community, and their community talks back. And they communicate often. Weekly - or so, ♥♥♥♥ happens - posts keep everyone appraised of what's going on with/in to the game, which is always nice to see. And I've seen some ♥♥♥♥, man... I purchased Cube World.

Now, I want to draw attention to something that I think is important. Stonehearth is currently in Alpha 10 - every time there's a large content update, they bump that number up by one. And it's only just now on Early Access, despite it going up on Steam early so Kickstarter patrons would have an easier time of it.
That means they waited until they had a significant amount of content in the game before going Early Access.

Seriously, Radiant. Y'all're beautiful.

If you like boxy sandboxes and RTS-type games, give this one a whirl. I think you'll like it.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I have been playing this game pre-EA release, and I can honestly say it is one of the most enjoyable casual games I have ever played. It has a perfect balance between city building, RPG elements and crafting, and gives you a rewarding feeling of progression. Each citizen has their own stats and skills that can be improved and you get a real sense of a village community developing. I'll just summerise the rest into simple pros and cons:

PRO
- Fantastic mix of city-building/RPG
- Simple yet very pretty graphics
- frequent updates and very good developer communication
- A slow yet steady rate of progression

CON
- villager professions not yet finished so feel abit lacking in variety
- a few bugs here and there
- can be hard at times as death of a skilled citizen can set you back for a while

I would strongly recommend giving this game a go and looking at the future plans for this game on the developers website, exciting things planned!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Stonehearth is a great game. It's a merge of Dwarf Fortress and Minecraft; The former for it's 'base-building' and management aspects, the latter for it's voxel graphics.

TL;DR Pros/Cons list:
+ Good replay value
+ Looks great
+ Large amount of craftable items and professions
+ Building Designer
+ Villagers level up and unlock skills
+ Frequently updated

- Rather buggy, villagers tend to get confused very often and so on
- Combat is slow and iffy at times
- Game will often break if you don't save often to avoid doing things that break it
- Some 'texture' issues
- Few pre-built structures
- Lack of game customisation (monster spawn rates, villagers, etc)

In Stonehearth, your goal (if any) is rather simple: to build a thriving medieval village/city, and take care of the various needs of your villagers (known has hearthlings) along the way.
You don't have direct control over your villagers like an RTS; you give them orders to perform and they'll find a way to do it (most of the time) themselves.

As you progress in-game, and your villagers level up, you'll slowly unlock more proffessions for them to practice, and thus more furniture, decoration, tools and weapons for them to use.
You will not, however, unlock new buildings, as the game only has 5 (I believe) pre-built ones. The rest is up to you to build, using the game's Building Designer feature, which works more or less the same as 'The Sims' Build Mode, with a tab bit less freedom.
Hearthlings tend to have issues when building; I have had to help them off of roofs, demolish a building because they couldn't build scaffolding or because they just go on strike and won't build anything at all.
Be sure to leave at least a block of space around a building when planning it out; your hearthlings won't be able to build the scaffolding if not.

Decoration-wise, there are tons to choose from, ranging from beds, to flower pots or braziers. Each crafting profession has some form of decoration. My villages have gotten prettier and prettier over time as I've discovered new crafts.

The game's replay value is rather high, as attempting to create a functional village in different environments can be a challenge at times (on top of a mountain, for example ^^).

The game is also rather buggy in it's current state; several times I have had to start a new game because I placed a path over another and the villagers refused to build anything else, or because I was planning a custom building and none of my orders would work anymore.
Many blocks/items sometimes overlay eachother as well, causing flickering textures which can get rather irritating at times.
I've also had issues where my one fighter hearthling has gotten themselves stuck in an infinite loop of 'Attack Golbing Chieftan > Run away from Goblin Chieftan'. Seeing as there is no direct control over the villagers, I can't do anything to get them to stop, and just have to wait for something to hopefully kill them.

All in all, Stonehearth is a great game to own if you're into the genre and I highly recommend it.The frequent updates make it a great game to come back to from time to time.
If I were to rate it out of 10 like everyone else seems to, I'd have to give it the following:

7/10.
For an Early Acces game, it has a good amount of content, looks good, is fun to play, but the bugs it has in it's current state sometimes ruin the experience.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I have followed and been trying this game out since the beginning. I first got hooked when it was a concept from someone that seemed to have a passion for what he wanted to do and what he wanted to make.

This game is the type of early Access that steam needs. More developers should actually follow this style. Here we have a guy that had his game available while in developement with it hardly being playable. We had the chance to see the game receive slow but steady streams of content flowing in and bug squashing. I used to not be able to get 5 minutes before everyone decided they wanted to sit around and do nothing. But unlike other developers, This guy actually kept at it. and unlike other developers. When the cash flowed in... they slowed down, He sped up.

The closest relation i can give this developer style is like Dwarf Fortress. Not in terms of gameplay, but how he steadily adds content while fixing issues with the game. and any dwarf loving fan will know that it takes a while for each of the updates to come out.

TL:DR - Developer set realistic goals to meet with limited resources. And keeps meeting them.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Well, it's finally here... Steam Early Access! I couldn't be happier for Team Radiant! :)

Disclaimer: I am an official fanboy, and hold this development studio in the highest esteem. But in my defense, I think this is perfectly justified given how open and transparent this team is with their fans and supporters.

All that aside, what do I actually think about Stonehearth? I think it has the potential to be one of the most entertaining games we've seen in these combined genres in ages. There's a wealth of things that the team has already implemented (building!, classes, crafting, mining, combat) and a whole host of others in the works.

With each new update the team trickles out improvements to the game's foundation (better performance, more stability) and introduces new mechanics and content as well for the community to test drive. You will be hard pressed to find another team that is as open with their backers as these folks, and its always rewarding to see topics discussed with the team in their bi-weekly stream actually implemented in the game.

I think I'll leave this review for now, and revisit as each new major release is dropped (roughly every month to month and a half). If you are at all interested in the title, I highly encourage to drop by the Discourse and mingle with some other fans and backers. Watch a few LP series and see just what Stonehearth has to offer at this stage of development.

I have a feeling you'll be glad you did! :)

p.s. if you are interested in watching a town be rebuilt ... *several* times, look no further! :p
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=jElqNfjbkFA

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Before I begin, let me say this:  I understand Stonehearth is in Early Access.  I don't expect everything to work flawlessly. That having been said, the game needs a lot of work.

I picked up Stonehearth based on a lot of Steam user reviews comparing it to Dwarf Fortress.  I like Dwarf Fortress, even though the game is notorious for its extremely obfuscated interface.  Stonehearth sacrifices a lot of DF's detailed simulation for a more accessible experience, which is fine with me.  However, as of March 2016, the current build is badly broken.

A few of the weird AI glitches I've seen include Hearthlings that join the settlement, but idle in one place permanently.  After accepting a new Hearthling (hereafter referred to as plebs")

recommended: regardless of any orders I issued.  She was eventually eaten by wolves.  Footmen

votesHelpful: they flee for a few moments
votesTotal: then turn back and resume fighting.  I've lost at least four Footmen because of this behavior.  Mobs also have a tendency to spawn in weird locations
votesFunny: like at the end of a long tunnel with only one entrance.  I got a notification informing me that one of my plebs was mauled to death by wolves
commentsCount: at the end of a mining tunnel with a closed door at the entrance.  Either something's up with the spawning algorithm
column16:
or all dogs don't go to heaven.

I'm saying they're ghost dogs.  Way of the samurai.

The building system is suprisingly robust.  The interface makes it easy to plot foundations
column17: walls
column18: upper floors
column19: and roofs.  I actually designed some pretty handsome structures
column20: and the process was fairly intuitive and straightforward.  However
column21: once I actually placed my blueprint and ordered my plebs to build the structure
column22: I ran into more AI issues.  On two separate occasions
column23: my plebs stopped building before the structure was complete.  They'd build to around 3/4 completion
column25: as though they had nothing to do.  Reloading the game did nothing.  Suspending all jobs
column26: then re-assigning them did nothing.  I simply had a partially-finished shell of a building in the middle of my settlement.  I tried to remove it
column27: but my plebs demolished about half of the building
column28: then idled again.  My town looks like Detroit in 1996.  Shameful display.\n\nDespite all the AI issues
column29: I still like the game.  The art style is charming
column30: and the UI makes it easy to place buildings and command your plebs.  Once they iron out the issues with plebs abandoning construction halfway through
column31: I think it's going to be a joy to play.  The interface handles walls and roofs very gracefully
column32: and building blueprints for structures is a breeze.  I remember placing roofs in "Towns
column33:
a similar town-building game, was a living nightmare.  Most importantly, while scanning the forums for solutions to my AI issues, I saw that the devs were very active, involved with, and respectful to their players.  That's a very good sign.

For the time being, I'm going to recommend this game.  I was excited enough about the premise that I didn't mind the $25 price tag, but if cost is an issue for you, I'd recommend holding off until they get a beta build up and running.  Bottom line:  despite some pretty rampant AI issues, the game shows a lot of promise.  As long as the devs stay active and listen to their player base, I think this is going to mature into a very enjoyable experience.

[UPDATE 3/13/16]  All of my footmen got thwomped by a one-two combo of ghost dogs and giant zombies, so I decided to start a new settlement in sandbox mode.  So far, I've experienced none of the AI glitches I saw in 'normal' mode.  It seems that something about combat, or placing my settlement on defense mode, breaks the AI.  I'm hoping the devs fix this, because I enjoyed the challenge of defending against sporadic attacks from invaders and thieves.  For the time being, however, I'd recommend you play in sandbox mode.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

In StoneHearth, you begin the game on a randomly generated map similar to a Minecraft map. The gameplay is similar to a strategy game, as you do not control directly any character. You just give orders and expect them to be followed. You start with 7 Settlers, each having their own sets of strenghts & weaknesses. One may be thriving in handcrafting while another is suited for military missions. With these settlers, you'll build and develop a camp thanks to all the resources available. These resources are various, and it can be compared here with Terraria for instance.

To grow, you'll focus on developing the skills of your settlers, assigning them jobs, and gathering as much resources as possible. But these objectives can be endangered by the presence of enemies at night: zombies, skeletons, goblins. You'll have to manage a small military force to protect yourself.

The final objective of the game in its current state is more or less to build your 'perfect base', and survive long enough to do so.

Similar games:
- Stronghold
- The Settlers

Cool features:
- Daily events and Trade, to earn gold and buy resources you lack of
- The Building design system, which is quite good and allow you to design your dream city/base
- Progression system for settlers

In its current state, the game is good, and the potential is interesting. I recommand it if you enjoy this kind of game (Check the Settlers especially).

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Mined a 8x8 pit,
forgot ladders,
villagers got hungry
and died

Would starve villagers again

10/10

Serious note:  This game is wonderful, Very kid friendly. Helps with imagination and pretty much build to your hearts content.

I have had no complaint since kickstarter. Yes it has bugs, (some quiet funny/EA) but it is very playable and will drain your hours away. The dev's are very communicative. Tom even streams every Tues and Thrusday with the community and listen to your input. Well all of Team Radiant listen to the community.  They have well rounded road map too.




PRO
- Great city-building/RPG
- Fun world
- 10x better then most building games (and its EA)
- Frequent updates, good developer communication
- Easy going graphics (especially on low end machines)
- Steady progression



CON
- Villager professions not alot of them yet (part of the progress)
- A.I. frustrations
- Bugs here and there
- Playing on story mode (no real story yet) can be difficult
- Drains Time :)


Little about how the game works

You start off picking your location. Get a handful of villager (random gen - could get all females/males) with campfire and banner.  Beginning by getting mats (wood and stone) placing your stockpile for them to place. You promote for a Carpentar and hunter to get food going. Need to keep those villagers fed. Then to the Farmer to mass the food production. As your handling this you have your workers building houses, from scatch (or blueprint), placing beds (for them to sleep) and other items of decor. If in story mode, the goblins with attempt to bribe you or get you raided. Here comes your first footman. As time goes and and your life has drained away you will have walls up with footman patrolling keeping those pesky goblins and undead in check. Your village will be growing, your workers mining and working, your craftman crafting and your village having life. Quite a site to see.

If your not into building villages, You can always go to peacful mode and build what you want. (I got a mages tower built floating in the air) But you can build almost what you want. As long as the villagers can reach it and build it. Still must keep them fed and have a place to sleep. But not much there but imagination.

I open up the game. My first opinion is that it looks beautiful. I create my City named Okai IGuess. Okai IGuess starts off wonderful. People nonstop build and whatnot. At first I'm really confused on what to do but quickly figure it out. Game is a bit laggy but I ignore it.

Realize I can construct my own buildings.
Create a freaking magnificant beast.
After a while all my citizens stop doing anything.
I realize 4 of my people are stuck in the top floor of my new mansion.
Realize I didn't add stairs or a way to get down.
4 of my people starve to death.
Rest of town gets depressed and stop working all together
Goblin king asks for stuff. I decline.
Goblin army attacks, my people start to defend then fall asleep on the ground.
Entire town gets ransacked and people starve and die as I watch helplessly.
10/10 would build mansion beast again.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nYou hate bugs?  So do I.  You hate that a game can be in Alpha for years on end?  So do I?  But have you been dreaming about building your own 8 bit RPG village from the ground up?  Afraid of all the freaking crap that you have to learn to play Dwarf Fortress?  Want to support a developer who is upfront about the struggle, needs the communities help, and is rewarding that community with continued work?  Well, this is the game.  This gives me hope that Steam Greenlight, Kickstarter, and indie gaming can make truly wonderful games that would of never seen the light a decade ago.

I understand this is alpha but once again we have an Early Access game where after a year the devs can't seem to manage fixing the core feature of their game   Town Building.

Yes this could be a great game but let me put it this way...    See all those buildings in the screen shots???      99% of the buildings in them will bug out before your citizens will complete them leaving you with a town full of half finished buildings each and ever time..     The suggested way to fix the game breaking bugs is to restart... then restart..... then save and restart..    have you tried restarting...    perhaps if you restart again.....     did I mention restarting..

New patch out...    sheep wont run away   but    Buildings still get hung up on bugs.   have you tried restarting?

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I've been following this game for a long time, I actually missed the kickstarter by a few days.. and it is unfortunate because I really wanted to support them in a bigger way. This game means quite a bit to me it really got me back into gaming which I was very apathetic about all newer game titles. I've been in the testing phases of this game for a long time pretty much as soon as they allowed you to buy in from their website and I honestly have never regretted it.

The game itself is quirky. There is a lot of stuff going on and bugs happen, but I can absolutely assure anyone who is put off by this that it will be fixed. In the older builds there were major funny, and breaking bugs.. which messed up the gameplay but the devise are always diligent to squash anything they can as promptly as possible.

I can't recommend this game enough simply because it has such an amazing community. It already has modders, the devs are very active and as transparent as possible, biweekly dev streams where people in chat can actually influence the shape of the game, devs are very appreciative of their community and open to suggestions, and much more. The team definitely has a vision of where this game is going, and they are honestly working their asses off to achieve it.. And so far they are hitting the nail on the head every time. Their over all may not be exactly what I was wanting... But the modding scene well have us covered on that front.

New builds come out every few weeks.. Sometimes they are buggy sometimes they are not. It all depends on what what changed or how much new content is thrown it. Fixes usually come within a few days but sometimes require a larger update to fix. I pretty much play this game for 5 or 10 hours every other weekend testing the new content, trying out new ideas, etc.. The content is steadily growing at decent rate.

Overall for me this game scratches an itch I've had since finally abandoning dwarf fortress. I look forward to participating in this community for years to come.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I've been following this game since it's Kickstarter days and am very pleased with the progress it has made thusfar. Stonehearth is a sandboxish city builder, simulation game with added rpg like elements. Whether you just want to build your dream village, fight off incoming invaders, or dig the deepest mine, this game has it all. Designing buildings has never been easier and allows for many possibilties and custimizations and your hearthlings will automatically build what you design for them. The profession system gives you various choices to decide which directions you want your little town.

Radiant Entertainment are some of the most community driven developers I have ever come across. They are constantly livestreaming the game development and intereacting with the community on the forums. As this game  has a tendency of having some (often hilarious) bugs here and there as any Alpha game does, the team is very quick at releasing patch versions to adress these kind of errors.

Modding is another core component in this game. Being new to moding myself, it is amazing to see how easy it is to mod the game, even in this early state, and should get much easier as the game develops. There is already a nice variety of community made mods available on the stonehearth forums.

All in all I definitly recomend this to anyone who loves city builders, rpgs and sandbox games.  If you are a hardcore Dwarf Fortress gamer, I suggest you give Stonehearth a try. With the progress Radiant has made so far, I am definitly excited to see what they have in store for multiplayer and the other features they want to add to this wonderful game!

~Avairian

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I have played this game off and on for about 6 months and can honestly recommend the game. It is still in development, but the developers are extremely engaged and regularly release updates with bug fixes, new content, etc. The core of the game is solid and offers significant room for customization of the buildings within your town. At present, there are bugs, but this is expected. What is promising is that many of the bugs I have observed over the course of the past 6 months, have been taken care of. Do new bugs pop up when new content is released? Of course. However, they are typically resolved within a month, at most, of the new content's release.

The game itself is primarily a city builder with random raids of goblins, undead, etc thrown in to keep the game play interesting and varied. The combat system is a bit wonky at present, but has been steadily improving over time which is a good indication of future improvements to come.

Resource gathering has become rather staightforward and it is relatively easy to keep your villagers gathering what you want them to. It does require a bit of micromanagement as there is not a way to automate their gathering behavior at present (e.g. mine when copper is below 20 in storage, gather wood when inventory is below 15, etc). Once the resources are gathered, though, the tradesmen can be completely automated to maintain inventory levels of the items you wish to produce (e.g. set the Blacksmith to maintain 5 swords in inventory, etc)

In sum, despite the bugs that I have experienced and room for future improvement, I would highly recommend this game. It has vast potential, a very active development team that is engaged with the community, and is generally enjoyable to play.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Stonehearth is one of those little games that make you feel like you're playing a SNES style RPG but in fact you're building the towns in said RPG and you get to see how the beginning was in said town. The goblin raids that went through your little village when you were nothing but a small team of builders trying to build up their first mess hall and houses for your people. How you were so helpless then and then near you complete your village and are happy with it you are very proud of it. The amount of time you spend and how much love and care you spent with each little villager with the classes and how you can see them work hard on any new structure you build from scratch.
The game is beautiful for a voxel game with the cell shading and voxel enviroment. Now the game takes every block from the world. Terraforming is actually pretty pleasing in this game, instead of games in which terraforming is make or break, this game makes it realatively pleasing in which i never saw any ugly in doing so. If you have the money and are interested in buying this game, do so, you'll love it if you're into the micromanaging/ builder genre. I personally bought the game when it was $30 and was on a kickstarter. This was in Alpha 7, it was still buggy but they ironed it out and added much more content in the span of 3 months. Now, the game is still in Alpha, but neither the less I would buy it. It'll easily make you go a good 15 or so hours on your first town. Even if it's in Alpha, you still have a lot to do.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I'll write this with the caveat that this game isn't finished being made at this time and is still in Alpha.

That said, I wholeheartedly reccomend it. As a citybuilder/manegment game Stonehearth shows great promise and while it's a bit thin in its currect state (Alpha, so missing a lot of features/content) it's still pretty competent overall. Oddly, my favorite feature isn't the game itself, but the team behind it; Radiant. Those dudes have some of the best community outreach in the business and they are always putting out dev blog updates, keeping the content comming at a pretty good clip and letting you know what's on the horizon when they can't do that. It's cute, it's chirpy, it's got the foundation for a truly great town manager. I particularly love the ability to build custom buildings with relative ease, though style options are slightly limited, what with still being in development.

There are a few Cons though; one, it's a slow game. Incredibly slow. Pace is apparently something on their list to work on, but as it is, I can only bear to play on fast and even then I feel like there should be a faster setting. There also aren't really any options for stockpile flow--the ability to have a particular stockpile pull from others, and it's one of the major things that's keeping Stonehearth from being truly great. This is also impacted by the speed (since your hearthlings have to walk AAAAALLL THE WAY to the stockpile, then ALLLL THE WAY back) which becomes more problematic as your town gets bigger.

I imagine some of the problems I have will get resolved as the game works its way through Alpha, and I'll update this review as new things get added, problems arise, and good stuff crops up. If you're hard up for a city builder, I only see this one getting better over time. If you're a bit more skittish, that's fair; but keep at eye on this and I encourage you to give it a shot when it's more complete.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

A Sandbox Strategy That Delivers
Stonehearth is a sandbox strategy game, set in a (light) fantasy setting, with town building, crafting, and a military campaign.

What Is It Like?

Take Dwarf Fortress. Tone down some of the rogue-like elements. Replace the esoteric production chains and mood  simulations with more accessible and managable alternatives. Add a charming 3D voxel art style with tons of character. Introduce some truly innovative mechanics, including the way hearthlings simulate building. Voila.

Or, for readers that haven't had the privilege of learning how losing is fun"
date: we'll try a more popular game for comparison. Take Minecraft
recommended: pull it back to  a strategic level
hoursPlayed: give yourself hearthlings to manage
voteText: add in a bunch of depth with jobs and production chains
helpfulPercent:
and smother it in buckets of charm. Welcome to Stonehearth.

What Sets It Apart From Other Sandbox Strategies?

Charming and effective 3D voxel art style.
Deep production chains that don't dive off the deep end (ie: stocking a hospital in Dwarf Fortress).
Promotes mixing form with function through a powerful and versatile building creator/editor.
Engaging
votesHelpful: visually appealing
votesTotal: and immersive construction simulation.\nDeep
votesFunny: yet accessible
commentsCount:
statistics and job system with fun role-playing elements.
Interactive military campaign that allows the player to engage in diplomacy or war.
Intelligent user-interface design maintains accessibility even in areas of the game with more complex mechanics.
The Bottom Line

I am recommending Stonehearth not only because it is already a successful sandbox strategy game in its own right

I want to review StoneHearth not Hearthstone StoneHearth now StoneHearth is a game that looks like Minecraft but plays completely different and is by far one of the most enjoyable games I have ever played, let's start with the pros and move to the cons.
Pro's
So first off one of the best things about this game is the fact that you can sculpt and design your own civilization making this one of the best for role playing games yet one of the best Sim games.
One of the coolest features of this game is that you can go ahead and build your own buildings from scratch and you can make your own Warriors and upgrade them using the crafting equipment you use you can fend off goblins and Invaders with your warriors and you can also trade with Traders and buy from Merchants that come to your town day and night.
One of my favorite things to watch happen is my town progress and my citizens gain level's. You can even have people come to your town and reward you for killing off goblins
Con's
One of the major issues with this game is the UI user interface it's extremely hard to work with, sometimes it glitches out and other times just completely shut's down and even makes you force shutdown the game.
One of the things that also really irritates me is the constant lag that occurs that is unpreventable no matter how much you Tinker with the options internally and (externally, outside the game) you cannot fix the lag issues I personally have constant issues with completing buildings and helping my citizens survive from goblins invaders, because the lag is so horrendously bad.
Now keep in mind this lag is so extremely hard to work around and it only starts when you progress into the game far enough. Errors will occur almost every single play-through and it really makes you wish that they had some sort of patch for people to work with instead they're going update by update.
Thing's I want to see happen
I wish that they would fix all performance issues and make it so your PC recognizes it as a game instead of a program.
I want them to make an online multiplayer addition so you can play with AI or other players.
I want them to make a campaign for story. Also add more action to the game so you can be full out assaulted and have to defend for like 5 minutes or longer.
I want them to FIX something I did not mention above, which is when you ask a group of people to work on something new you can choose which citizens you wantr to work there so you have a spreadsheet. For example okay I want 3 citizens harvesting wood 7 citizens building a mansion and your guards to patrol in a certain pattern you choose.
Also larger worlds, larger threats as you progress so it won't be a breeze to clear out 6 invaders with 1 guard(with a wooden sword)
Other than that this game is FREAKING AWESOME. At it's current stage it's fantastic minus all the performance issues. 8.3/10

reviewText:
Early Access Review

**As a forewarning, there are minor spoilers. There really isn't much of a storyline, but I go in depth as far as gameplay goes.**

So I spent a good few hours on the game, getting a feel and really seeing what it has to offer. The fact that it is in alpha was a little worrysome, given how many games are labeled with early access and seem to die without much improvement or support. This game, so it seems, is different.

It's a refreshing change, it's truly quite unique in multiple aspects ranging from gameplay to art and design. This game is most certainly sandbox in nature, but it actually carries a very strong similarity to Dwarf Fortress, and almost seems like a branched-off, reskinned version of it. I can only imagine the vast amount of direction and improvement this game has in store if only the developers remain diligent and active.

To start.. As of the current build -524, you have the option of choosing a biome, starting location, and race. I haven't experimented heavily with these options; I've only had the pleasure of one play in which I haven't come all that far. That being said, once you choose your world, you then choose where in said world you will build your camp. Naturally, you'll want to choose an area with plenty of trees, wildlife, and minerals. Upon choosing, you're dumped off without much of a tutorial, which usually seems like an overwhelming experience, however.. This game is fairly straight foreward. After a few minutes, I quickly learned my way around the UI, the different tools, navigation, and issueing commands to my Hearthlings. Before long, the first raid on my settlement had taken progress. I immediately knew the general idea of what to do, click the large, red sword icon, right? It was as simple as that; my Hearthlings ran to a safe position as my assigned soldiers made short work of the beast. As of right now, the game doesn't seem to be too unforgiving. I am expecting that to change as I come further along and mine deeper into the ground.

Graphically speaking, this game is very crisp and clean. There are a few annoyances which are more gameplay issues than graphics, but I'll get to those in a bit. The game has a bit of a minecraft appearance, but one with customer shaders and higher quality picture. Textures are almost non existant, but I can do without those, it simply works for this game. All in all, there isn't a whole lot of clutter, which can really turn into a big problem for games like this.

In terms of bugs, this game definitely has its share, but it's to be expected. I feel confident that more and more bugs will be fixed as time continues, the support website seems very much alive with devs attempting to help those who experience issues. A few bugs I've personally come across include goblins exploding into sunlight instead of fighting my soldiers, a Hearthling that never wakes up from his sleep, and not being to change to a specific class despite having met all requirements. Obviously two of these can be considered game breaking, however I'm not letting it kill my opinion of this game. Save often is the best fix for most problems.

As for one final in-depth review, this game is, as I mentioned, like a replica of Dward Fortress, though with FAR less features. I suspect this game is very heavily influenced by Dwarf Fortress. You have the ability to custom-build structures, or choose from a preset list. You can place said structures where ever they fit. You can alter the environment by taking down trees, creating mines, etc. As you create mines, it really opens up many different possibilities for construction ideas. Perhaps an underground fortress? All in all, in the short amount of time that I've played this game, I'm enjoying it a lot. If they can implement some more features or similarities from DF such as complex contraptions, many more monsters and biomes, etc, I'll be thrilled. Perhaps even a mode to take complete control of a single, hero-like individual to explore the lands, loot, plunder dungeons, and seek bounties, much like DF. I might be going a little far comparing the two, but regardless, the game can (hopefully) only improve from here.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Stonehearth is a brilliant game considering that it is an early alpha. If you've ever play'd a game called 'RimWorld' It's much like that. Stonehearth is like a village management game, you gain a new civ every night [If you reach the days goal E.g. Enough wealth, Happiness & Food] This goal is meant to get harder as the game goes on, but it isn't really that hard to reach.

Con's-The building in Stonehearth could use some improvements and I'm sure the developers will make this mechanic better. Once you place a building it cannot be removed.

-You are not able to build easily inside E.g. In a cave/ Mountain.

-When the goblins start to raid, it seems like they never stop coming night after night. They could use tuning down [Spawning less]

Pro's-So far I have experienced very little lag, to fix this all I did was re-load the game.

-There're soo many options for the civ's. For example you can appoint them different jobs such as Warrior, Cook, Farmer, Trapper... Each with a new set of uniform & tools.

-Very attractive game. Although the graphics are not Arma 3 standard, it doesn't need to be - the games graphics suit the game, the blocks have near enough a plain texture and puts less strain on your PC.

-When your village does get attacked, It's not like a few games out there, where you're entire village would get destroyed Age Of Empires, I'm looking at you here.

I've stopped playing StoneHearth for now, not because It's a bad game but because I'm waiting for more items to be implemented into the game.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game is absolutely amazing. Even in the alpha stage, I think it’s the best game I’ve played in a long time. I posted a negative review about this already, but all the cons I'd noted were immediately proven wrong.

The pros:

+The graphics are pretty good for what it’s supposed to be
+The music is brilliant
+The developers update it quite often
+You can build your own buildings in any way you want
+The class development system is very good
+There are a few quests in the game at this point to give you a purpose
+There is essentially an infinite amount of resources
+It rarely crashes (in my experience, at least)
+The bugs are few and far between
+It’s a cute sandbox city builder that’s a lot of fun

The cons:

-It is a little bit buggy at points
-It’s addicting

This game is still in alpha at this point, so it’s bound to have a few bugs here and there, but the bugs I’ve come across haven’t really affected my gameplay at all. I mean, I have built a few things that my Hearthlings have picked up and stolen, the thieving so-and-so’s, but other than that, I haven’t encountered a bug that’s really made things a bother in any way.

I started playing this game expecting a lot less than what I got. I thought I’d give it a try and then forget all about it, but I was wrong. As soon as I passed the hour mark, I was hooked. It’s just so much fun that I can’t stop. Seriously, nothing else I’ve played has been this addicting.

TL;DR: It’s a lot of fun, it’s a little buggy, but the developers update it quite often and it’s already amazing anyway.

I just can’t wait for the full release.

First Steam review here, so go easy on me please!

I had been following Stonehearth since its Kickstarter campaign back in 2013, and I finally bit the bullet back in August.  Since then I have enjoyed (almost) every minute of gameplay.  As many reviewers have noted, this is really a niche game, and if you are into a slow-paced city building sim with some RPG and RTS stuff mixed in, this is the game for you.  For me, I love setting up my little town so that it is self-sustaining, and then sitting back and watching.  Seeing the little Hearthlings running around, farming, shepherding, and cooking, all the while getting hungry and eating, and eventually relaxing by the fire and sleeping, it is really quite pretty to see. reviewText:
Early Access Review

I have a lot of games in my steam library but this is the one I keep coming back to. This is the kind of game I can lose myself in, starting a play session, getting really focused on building and defending my town, and then I look at my clock and 6 hours have somehow gone by.

The latest focus on combat and hardmode have brought a much more intense feeling to the game. Enemies can catch you offguard if you don't think about all angles you need to defend, and the new RPG classes have added a lot of depth to the combat side of the game. As far as developing your town/fort/city-whatever goes I becom a kid again, playing with lego.

This is in alpha, so there are still a lot of glitches, missing features, and polish that is getting fixed/added. Building elaborate structures is usually very difficult especially getting the hearthlings to construct them. You can cheat structures in with console commands, but hopefully some day you won't ever need to use commands again and the little guys will be able to make anything you want.

One of the best things about this game is it's devs. They are very community focused and they actually stream on twitch coding and art sessions three times a week. They aren't very active on the steam community hub, but on their own website's discourse they are very active.

I really recommend this game even in it's current alpha state. Very enjoyable building game with some decent RTS RPG style gameplay.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

First and foremost you need to understand that Stonehearth is currently in ALPHA. This means there will be bugs, unoptimized code, and a range of other things that appear in alpha level content.

Although Stonehearth isn't a revolutionary game, it is still very enjoyable. Even though I’ve only owned the game since Alpha 9, I have spent enough time in the game to get a good feel for the gameplay, features, and overall value of the game. At this point in development I can recommend the game for those looking for a fun game, but aren’t afraid to test out builds, and find bugs.

In the games current state your goal is to not kill all your hearthlings. When starting the game you are given virtually nothing to survive other than a tool to make a carpenter and a trapper. From there your job is to craft tools, give hearthlings jobs, and start to grow a tiny civilization. If you are playing on the Peaceful game mode then you really don’t have anything to worry about beyond keeping your hearthlings well fed. The other game mode at this time is Normal, and includes some nice goblins for you to fight with. The goblins don’t make the game overly difficult at this time and really just add another degree of play. Personally I enjoy playing Normal since it can be somewhat boring playing on peaceful mode.

As of Alpha 10 the goblins haven’t been in the game very long. They do a nice job of adding more gameplay options though. With the inclusion of goblins you will need to take defense into consideration while building. They will not attack you immediately upon starting a game, but they do increase in difficulty as you grow stronger.

One of the strongest points this game has is the robust building mechanic. You can build whatever structures you can imagine, as long as it’s within the boundaries of tiny blocks. The build mode is very simple to use and really help you personalize it to your taste. When you get a structure created you can even save it to use at any time after that. It’s a really nice feature since you don’t have to worry about designing each building every time you need it. The game also allows you to edit the building before placing it, giving you a chance to personalize each one without the need to recreate it from scratch. The only issue I have found when designing the buildings you can’t add in items like desks, beds, chairs, or other things of that nature without having them created and sitting in your stockpile. Luckily you just need 1 on hand to add them into the building blueprint.

At this time the hearthlings don’t really have traits, but they do have stats. The stats are things like speed, courage, diligence, etc. and can affect how well a hearthling does his/her given job. As development continues I am sure we will see more stats, traits, and other features added to the individual hearthlings.

That is really just a rundown of the main features the game has at this time. If you are interested in learning more about the game feel free to join us over at the Stonehearth.net forums. We always have some discussion going about the game, and keep up with all the little bugs in need of squashing. You can also find my pros/cons breakdown below.

PROS
- Music
- Art style
- Crafting system
- Builing/Blueprint system is awesome
- Fun factor
-Replayability
-Great development team

CONS
- Occasional building issues
- LUA issues(LUA hits 100% causing game to lag and freeze)
- Ocassional errors while playing
- Lighting/Shadow issues

The only con that I’ve found to really be a hindrance is the LUA problem the game runs into. You can see the game resources in real time while playing via a small bar on the bottom right of the game client. Once the LUA usage hits 100% the game will lag completely out. This is a known issue and will hopefully be addressed soon.

I like this game a lot, it is a very good game and has some very good elements to it:

Things to fix though:
-(Not something needing fixed exactly) A way to delete the buildings I saved that I no longer want
-Villager's heads sink into/float above their bodies when working and/or walk while sitting down

Things I'd like to see in game:
-Ruined villages
-Multiple structures/tasks can be built/done at one time

-Villagers can marry/have kids

-Multiple roofs on buildings aren't required to have the same settings (i.e. overhang, height, etc)
-A villager is stuck alert (i.e. my villager was stuck up on scafolding, it took me awhile to figure it out)
-Be allowed to change game mode from sandbox to survival and vice versa
-Doors shouldn't open if someone is sleeping near it

reviewText:
Early Access Review

tl;dr Alpha 10 review:Cons:
Lot's of bugs, minimal content.  Basically, it's a work in progress alpha game.
Pros:
Excellent dev team, great mod support, fun game with lots of potential.

If you want a polished, feature filled, bug free game then stick StoneHearth in your watch list and wait a bit.

If this looks like your kind of game, you want to have input into the development, you don't mind playing a game that will crash on you or just break because you clicked a button that causes an error, and you want to support Team Radiant.  Then buy it now.

Full Alpha 10 ReviewIntro
When you buy an early access game you are not just buying the game, because that isn't ready yet.  You are buying a look into the development of the game and the team behind it, and you get to play along as it's made, and then get the finished product at the end of it.  In my opinion the team at Radiant Entertainment are an amazing developer and I would happily buy into another early access game from them in the future based on my experience with them so far.
What started out as a 2 man team when they launched their kickstarter has grown steadily over the past couple of years.  They have always interacted with the community with regular updates on their Dev Blog[stonehearth.net], answering questions, and helping on their Forum[discourse.stonehearth.net], and regular (currently multiple times per week) streaming through Twitch[www.twitch.tv] where they listen to and make changes from live feedback in the chat stream, explain the processes they are going through to help modding, and answer any questions people have for them about the game and it's development.
I have total faith that this game will see it's completion and continued support afterwards.

The Game (so far)
You start with a small band of settlers with limited supplies and tools with the aim of building up a small town.  This is acheived harvesting materials, creating jobs, building items and tools, creating buildings (pre made and custom), and defending yourself from enemies.

Controlling your town is a a bit of mix at the moment between telling your Hearthlings (the citizens) to go do something and then being able to forget about it (such as farming), and having to heavily micro manage other aspects (such as controlling production of individual items).  The initial concept from the kickstarter was that you wouldn't have to micro manage things in the town, so I would hope that this will be the case as the game matures.

The building aspect of the game is developing well, and has had new features added with each new alpha.  You can choose to use a selection of pre-designed houses/buildings from Radiant or go all out and custom design your own.  The custom buildings part of the game is where I personally have experienced the most game breaking bugs, but it is certainaly getting better all the time.  If this is the part you are most looking at this game for I would hold off for a bit.

Each Hearthling can be assigned a job/role within the community and will improve as they perform their tasks.  These include farmers, trappers, craftsmen, and guards.  These all work pretty well, although are all work in progress with the higher end skills still to be implemented.  And there are also new professions being added with each update.  Aplha 11 will be bringing us a cook, no more raw food!

Enemies currently come in two varieties; undead, which will spawn on random nights and head to your town; and the goblins which are currently being worked on as part of the campaign that runs in game.  You do have the option to play on peacful mode if you want to build in peace and quite without having to worry about defending yourself.

Modding
StoneHearth has been built from the ground up to support modding, and already has several great mods available, adding extra content into the game, changing the themes of the game and more projects in the works.  Because the game supports mods at it's core it is as simple as downloading a mod from the forum and dropping into the games mod folder.

Final Thoughts
StoneHearth has a great team behind it, and is showing great potential for being an amazing game.  In it's current state you can definitly get several hours of enjoyment from the game, and get a taster of what is to come.  If you decide to purchase now expect to see bugs every game, from the amusing floating helmets, to annoying error messages, and I would recommend using the pre-made building templates until you are familiar with the rest of the game before venturing into more complex custom buildings.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I kickstarted Stonehearth and have been playing it since it was very, very simple in nature.  The graphics have remained beautiful (if you like voxels) throughout, each iteration has led to massive improvements in gameplay, and a number of bugs have been fixed - and the game is still in alpha.

One of the big deals" about this game is that it takes the dwarf fortress approach to items in the world and materials.  It then layers LUA scripting and html (no joke) for the interface.  Its modding system isn't a modding system so much a content-delivery system.  You want a new race? Describe some things in JSON and boom.

This leads to some very
date: very awesome potential for BETA once all the systems are fleshed out.  The latest update added the second Kingdom
recommended: and playing as it evolves into a completely different playstyle.. and as near as I can tell it wasn't much of a code update
hoursPlayed: just a "mod" from the dev's standpoint.\n\nThis is working out to be the ultimate kingdom builder / simulator.  Like Dwarf Fortress? You're gonna love this.  Like Minecraft but don't like doing all the digging yourself? You'll love it.  Do you like casual games? Yep."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Stonehearth is a fantastic game!!
It's cute little city-builder with some strategy and RPG elements

You establish your own little town, in a randomly generated world

Assign classes you your Hearthlings/Villagers. Like footmen, carpender, weaver, farmer. etc

Design your own buildings, draw out the walls and place furniture. Build bridges, statues, stairs and everything you can think of voxel-by-voxel with the slab tool
(But don't go to crazy, the automatic scaffolding system can't handle too complex structures yet)

Mine out the mountains for ore, and make your blacksmith create weapons & armor out of them.

And you need to protect yourself from Goblins, zombies and wolfs (And there is more to come).

Different races are planned, like Three different human clans, Rabbit people, Dwarfs and Orcs (some will be playable and some will not)

It's already a fun game and the developer has such plans for this game. This game has so much potensial, and i love it so much. The developers are really connected with the players, both trough the forums and the multiple streams they have weekly. And they are sure to take your thoughts to account.

The game is already fun, it just needs more content

I've had a lot of fun with this game and i would absolutely recommend it to everyone. Yes it's buggy but it is an alpha

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Stonehearth has many of the characteristics of Dwarf Fortress (DF): a simcity style game that focuses on individual citizens, their lives, attributes, and abilities.  It does not however, have the difficult learning curve that makes DF so in-accessible for people. Also, it has beautiful graphics, and has the option for a peaceful setup (for those not interested in fighting).

It has come a long way since the first alpha release for the Kickstarter backers (I joined post Kickstarter): the team is dedicated, and has been steadily working at improving the game, adding features.

It is by no means complete - but the team has been steadily working on the core functionality - and the promised set of features is large - multiple races, digging, and many more.
The development page which tracks features to be added is worth visiting.

The game also supports modding (which was built into the game from the start), which means that the final version should have lot of replay value / add-on value once the community creates mods.

Definitely a game worth supporting.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Have been playing this game off and on since the first Alpha. I've been through a lot of failed Kickstarter games, Castle Story, StarForge, a lot of disappointments like Planetary Annihilation, War for the Overworld, Shroud of the Avatar.

This game I still believe in. They've been making steady progress, they've stuck to what they said they were going to do on the kickstarter and the game has come from a single block with one towns person that picked berries to a playable town management game.

If you're looking for a finished product, this isn't it. Add it to your wishlist, come back around Christmas and see where it is. But if you're looking for a game that brings the feeling of Banished, Myth and Minecraft and mixes them all together then I suggest you take a closer look and consider supporting the game early.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

TL;DR - Buy it now, You most likely won't be disappointed!

A truly excellent game, well worth the money. I've followed the game and development team for 1 1/2 years and they put other Early Access developers to shame. They always keep in contact with us players, and are very transparent (hosting livestreams twice a week - where they show content being developed, and answer questions, and take suggestions/ideas, weekly development blog posts, responding to PMs and threads on the official forums, etc.). When you buy this game expect monthly-ish updates and alongside that pre-release versions to test out. (Very few Early Access games, update this often at all.)

The community is also awesome. Check out the official forums where you'll find lots of mods, artwork, animations, Let's Plays,  interesting discussions and very mature and respectable people.

I really love this game, and its admirable and impressionable devs. I can tell you right now this is not your typical let-down Early Access game! I can say full-heart'dly to buy this game. It's 100% worth it.

Please note though, if you buy this game right now. It's still EARLY ACCESS, and things such as optimization or promised features are not all completed yet. The devs have worked really hard, and I hate seeing people flame the game, while blindly ignoring the fact that it still has a while to go in development.

As of now there is plenty of content, and it's fairly replayable. It runs quite smoothly for an Early Access game, too. I say go for it, but if you're picky maybe wait a while! :)

[ P.S. - If you buy the game, please watch the weekly livesteams almost every Tuesday and Thursday - and also join the official forums, again really awesome community! :)! ]

reviewText:
Early Access Review

TL:DR Do you have a realistic expectation of alpha/early access games? Are you willing to wait for more features and enjoy the current game in the mean time? Do you like the genre of this game?
If you ansered yes, this game is for you.

I have been playing this game pre-EA release, and honestly believe it is one of the most satisfying kickstarters I have ever backed and is already quite fun to play. It has a brilliant balance of city building, crafting and RPG elements, and rewards the player with a real feeling of progression. Each citizen has their own stats and skills which you can improve and you are able to get very creative with your architecture already with a little effort.

PRO
- Developer communication, every week there are numerous posts on their websites dev blog covering their progress and frequent developer streams where you may have direct imput in the creation of the game.
- The game is being designed to be ULTRA modder friendly, I myself, someone with NO prior experience making mods have already made a few myself without causing bugs in the game in an alpha state. (Expect workshop support)
- Frequent updates, the game is beginning to progress rather quickly and is adding features and busting bugs EVERY patch.
- A wonderful art style, it maintains a simple charm while still looking brilliant and handling rather well even on less powerful machines.
- Balanced progression, the game in this current state is slow enough to last but fast enough to hold your attention.
- A fast forward button, I personally find this extremely important for things such as building or mining, or passing time while not active.

CON
- This is an alpha, EXPECT bugs. For an alpha it is a relatively low amount I have seen and they will be fixed soon enough but there WILL be bugs and if you go in to an early access game not expecting bugs you will be dissapointed.
- Villager progression through classes is currently limited, only a few are implemented so far which does reduce the games variety.
- can be hard at times as death of a skilled citizen can set you back for a while.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

It is very rare that I log in to make a review. By that I mean (and I don't know if others have this issue) when steam connects me to make one it brings me to a new window where I am not logged in. But that is neither here nor there.

Let me begin by saying this game has AMAZING POTENTIAL! However currently the villagers' AI is lacking though it is still an alpha build. Even then the game is still playable though you'll have many of your troopers standing around staring off into the sun like idiots.

The great pros to the game:

Great potential.

Good graphics that aren't hard on your computer (I'm on a laptop, furthermore one built for office work and NOT gaming and I still rarely crash).

The ability to build ANYTHING! Yes... anything! You can even build a giant hotdog if you wish.
A city builder that isn't annoyingly complicated.


The bad:

Well, the AI sucks as forementioned. That's a work in progress I hope.

Goblin attacks happen very early. I only had a carpenter and I was still working on making a guard when the first attack happened. I lost three of my five villagers. So yes, this is a bad thing but this also hasn't happened every game so perhaps it is just bad luck.

Villagers don't seem to really want to work but that's probably just the AI again. Also, there needs to be a method to making each villager assigned to a specific home or shop area. I have farmers sleeping in buildings on the opposite side of town to their fields and blacksmiths sleeping outside the town entirely...
voteText: 14 of 17 people (82%) found this review helpful 1 person found this review funny

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Stonehearth is a title i have many mixed opinions on. The development team behind it has been super friendly and open with the community about their progress. They've provided a steady stream of updates since they launched their series of alphas and their weekly dev blogs are a good way to see what they're working on.

That said their progress hasn't been particularly impressive, there are many bugs and glitches and essentially a time limit as the ai eventually becomes so bogged down that the game slows to a crawl. Even one of their recent updates which added more interesting enemy types, only served to bog the game down.

Even the coolest part of the game, how it lets you handcraft buildings is constantly held back by bugs and glitches. When it works you'll marvel at how cool your designs are, however when it doesnt work you'll wonder why the workers are so inept at something that in my opinion is a core feature of the game. If they could just get this one feature to work flawlessly it would probably single handedly make this game worth playing.

Supposedly their process for adding content is completed and things like new classes, and enemy types are being added regularly. However things like co op, and their AI storyteller have seen little to no progress. The former hasn't even been started and considering all the technical hurdles they've had to overcome to just get this far, chances are multiplayer will be a loooooong way off if not abandoned, as they're already well into their second year of development.

I suppose this is the nature of early access/ kickstarter. Despite how i've enjoyed this game on and off for these past years, the whole experience has just served to put me off on the idea of early access in general. In it's current state there's enough to keep you interested for a few hours, however sooner or later something will happen, some bug or glitch that will make you want to reload, start over, or quit till a new update.

TLDR; this is definitely a game to watch, but they have a long road ahead of them. If i could do it again, I would have probably not bought into the kickstarter.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Stonehearth, Stonehearth, Stonehearth...
Where do I even begin? I absolutely adore this game. I have learned about it some time ago and purchased it via Humble Bundle. Since then, I fell in love with it like never before, as this game is my dream game, one I have always been looking for. It is excellent mix of Strategy, Sandbox and City Simulation. This game, as you can probably tell by the screenshots and movies, have it`s own unique feel and it`s as cuddly and cute as it can get.
For now, the game is still in early to mid alpha, so there is much content to add, but even now game can be and is fun to play.

Why should you buy this game?
Developers of Stonehearth, team Radiant, are the most amazing team of developers I have ever encountered in my gaming career. You wouldn`t probably believe how much they involve us (the community) onto the process of making game. First of all, they stream on http://twitch.tv three times per week, showing us how the game is being made, also taking countless advices from players (you could affect how the monster will look in game, how some mechanics should work or even name characters yourself). They also let us decide on how the game`s development should go from alpha to alpha (using https://trello.com/b/4XvM0SUd/stonehearth-community-roadmap) so we can choose what content should be made next.

The game have an amazing building system, presented in the trailer. Your little Hearthlings will build everything you can imagine voxel by voxel, using scaffoldings. The building system is very intuitive yet complex, and is being updated even more.

Stonehearth is made in a way that allows players to easily add mods to the game. There already some amazing mods made by community members, and we can expect even more of those coming soon.

If you, like me, always want the game to be as filled with content as possible, you can expect some good things from Stonehearth, In the final version there will be alternative planes, additional biomes, extra races to play as, huge campains to play, dozens of enemies and events randomed by computer Game Master. And much more, that`s for sure.

Last but not least, you don`t have to be afraid of this game being abandoned by developers. They seem so excited about this game, and they don`t slow down while making this game in front of our eyes. I believe it`s a privilege being able to take part of making this awesome game.
I r8 8/8 m8.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

To address people raging about this game so far, I’ll repeat what others have already stated. The game is in development, and it will get better. With that in mind I’ve loved this game so far, and it’s been the easiest timesoak game I’ve had for years.

This game, in a word is pleasant. I've played games like Banished (which is probably the nearest comparable) where the biggest problem was keeping people alive, and the only way to do so was to go balls out at it deal with problems decades in advance.

This, like I've said is pleasant to the point of a city-building game being relaxing. I personally play games to chill out with, and I've always enoyed games within this genre so getting something I can actually chill out with is wonderful.

It's easy to understand, easy to progress through and at the time of writing (04/07/15) there are very few problems with it in terms of bugs that I’ve experienced, but I’ll detail any below. I do also have one or two suggestions but I'll detail those at the bottom. (Again, all in development stage. I don’t expect these to be addressed three weeks ago, chill your beans)

On the whole though, I've thouroughly enjoyed what these guys have offered already, and I can't wait to see what comes up in the future. It's a solid game as it stands, and it's far from a regretable purchase.

-- For the below, I'm just assuming the devs are watching these things --

Bugs I’ve noticed
I was able to place single tables within dining tables after building the wrong tables. I don’t know if this is unique but moving things around to get it straightened out was a ballache.

Suggestions
The daily report – while I fully respect people’s desire to blast through games like this. A play through on peaceful mode (for example) where you play at a fairly slow pace leads to a situation where you can’t keep up with the daily goals. If these goals were changed from what seems to be programmed based on what day you’re on, to a flat ‘Achieve this level of food/happiness/net value to get a new person’ the whole thing would flow a lot better.

A priority system, or a worker grouping could be set so sorting to storage can be made more efficient. For instance If I can make Phil gather a set range of materials (or if stores are refined enough, just tie workers to those stores). That or create a 'Runner' class of citizen, where their tasks is simply to move things around. (Teamster to the likes of Tropico)

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Stonehearth is a fantastic game, and if you enjoy sandbox/city building games then I highly recommend it.

I may be a little biased as I was one of the backers when it was still in Kickstarter, but even then I felt that Radiant Entertainment had a great take on the genre, and a great culture in regards to their backers and fans.  In watching the game and the team grow, I have not changed my mind.  They have shown consistent and impressive improvements to the game, regular updates on the game and the team, and an active role in the discussions.

A few notes on the game itself.  It is still very much a work in progress.  Features are still being developed and released, each one coming with it's share of bugs and quirks.  As should go without saying with any Early Access game, only purchase if you are interested in seeing the game grow, and want the chance to add your voice to the development.  Radiant has done a very good job of adding polish to the game as they went, but their primary focus has been features, the rest of the polish comes later.  That being said, I thoroughly enjoy this game, even in it's unfinished state.  Radiant has built a good base for their game, and I look forward to seeing what they can do with it.

-NB

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I am quite a big fan of the genre, and have enjoyed related titles a lot. Stonehearth has everything it needs to fill the  form:
- Villagers with names and faces (...and stats and opinions!)
- Random maps (...and varying biomes)
- Crafting / industry (...and leveling craftsmen)
- Resource management (...and storage management)
- Trade (...and trade missions/events)
- Town defense (...and giant zombies).

But it doesn't stop at that, the best thing about this game is that it oozes love. It's being crafted with TONS of love. The devs really care for this product, and it shows. It even inspired me to write them a small letter, to which they kindly replied.

That said, Stonehearth still has a long way to go until it's a solid, solid release, but I am extremely optimistic about the outcome and wish both develolpers and early adopters the best of luck.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nFor an alpha game this has a ton of promise. I am still very excited that the devs for this game are really behind this and whenever there is an issue its fix ASAP, not something you can get for most other games these days. It is simple to learn and allows you to be very creative in your builds. You control your town and your hearthlings and the outcome of the game. I highly recommend this game to anyone who loves to build and control a town of people. Even if you don't normally like this kind of game or if you get bored with them, this one adds other clans to make it a bit more challenging. Of course if you want a calm game there is a mode for that too! Hell you can even choose what kind of people to start with and have a completely different experience playing all over again. I got this game on the steam sale but even then I would have paid full price for this. A game where the Devs are actually working on the game still AND interacting with the community make this a great game so far and I would buy it again if I had to. Just remember it is still a work in progress, but that does not mean its not worth it as it is right now.

Early Access Review

Its got little block peeps!

Seriously though, if you have played Timber & Stone and liked that game, you will be sure to like this game! Development is top notch! I've not seen any other indy dev team so focused on progression and community input as Radient!

Its alpha, so its buggy, but there are constant updates that try to make each alpha release stable. And alpha releases come at nice intervals.

My only issue is that every alpha breaks saved games. So although you can save, you cannot progress in alpha builds if you are hard set on a settlement and don't want to lose it. This may change in the immediate future but as of my last game it has not.

TBH, Stonehearth is the only website where I track & post on for indy games. I support alot of indy games but none is as ambitious as this one, with a team so focused and honest.

If you do not own this game, you need to buy it! I'd bet my bottem dollar that this is a game that will see final relese, and  will be a game changer across its genre's!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Even though I recommended this game, I wouldn't get it just yet. It's so buggy that it is absolutely unplayable. The developers update it regularly and I have full expectations that it will be one of the greatest city-building games ever made when it is finished.

It's essentially Minecraft mixed with Banished. You assign jobs and tasks that need to be done, and your little hearthlings go do it. You don't controll the hearthlings directly, you simply guide them. They can die from combat and starvation, so careful planning and resource management is very important. It's as much a game of strategy as it is creation.

The game is currently somewhat limited in the designs you can create based on the terrible AI of your hearthlings and the bad UI. It will get fixed, and when it does, you'll be able to create things on par with Minecraft. All while playing a sandbox citybuilder.

When this game is out of the alpha stage, GET IT GET IT GET IT!!!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

On its way to becoming a great game, but what game that is exactly remains to be seen.

What's in the game now, is playable and fun, but also fairly bare-bones.  A lot of essential features are still missing. Being unable to tear down anything you've built being the big one. But there is a solid foundation and a lot of promise for the future and the devs are great at instilling confidence that they'll get there.

Currently the game seems a bit torn between macro and micro management. The devs are constantly struggling with how much they want the game to play itself". You can quickly and easily design custom buildings or plop down existing ones from templates. Farms are plotted out and then self-sufficient. But then you have to go in and tell your carpenter exactly how many beds
hoursPlayed: fense posts
voteText: etc to make for the buildings you're planning.  Most of the game so far is "set and forget" but then you have to keep a close eye on your crafters to keep them producing what you need.  I could do without that part myself. I'd rather be the city planner than micro-manage the supply chain.\n\nCombat is very basic right now. You have guards you can make better gear for
helpfulPercent: and set areas to patrol or attack but you have no direct control over them. It's more about "were you prepared ahead of time" than skill or micro-management.  This approach could work I think but there needs to be a lot more to it. Hopefully new additions like ranged combat that are being worked on will do just that.  If not
votesHelpful: I think they might do well to have combat be the one area they allow micro management to play a key role in player engagement.\n\nOne thing is for sure
votesTotal: Team Radiant is handling the game's development very well. Communication is definitely one of their strong points. The community is always in the loop and updates are consistent and substantial. Bugs are common but generally fixed quickly.  I get the impression development has gone substantially slower than they initially anticipated but their commitment to see it through is rock solid.\n\nThe game seems destined to be good at the very least
votesFunny: so it's an easy recommendation. It just remains to be seen if Radiant has the design chops and polish in them to make it great."
