reviewText:
Early Access Review

This is a beautiful voxel sandbox sim, inspired by dwarf fortress. In its present state it has a good portion of the core features implemented, but it is far from finished. It is very playable, but like other early access titles it does succumb from bugs and glitches. However the Devs are consistantly finding and squashing bugs. This game is updated regularly and the Devs are very open about where the game is at and what is being worked on for each new update (except for a few suprises here and there). This is a fantastic game with a great concept, and if you don't mind an early access with a bug or two its definately worth checking out.

I backed this title on kickstarter and have been following its progress ever since. It has been steadily improving bit by bit and its amazing to see how far its come. The Dev's have been amazing and have provided a real treat with regular twitch streams showing them working on various parts of the game, allowing the community that has grown around them to get a real good look at what goes into making this game and sometimes having a profound impact in the games evolution.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

First off let me say this: I DO recommend this game, because it's proof of consept is so grand, and it promises everything I have always wanted in a base-building game. That being said the price of $25 is a little steep for a game that is barely playable. I have put about 20 hours into it off steam, and will surely put more.

If you are  reading this i am sure you understand the game is in ALPHA and is pretty buggy, however the devs are great at talking to their community and are squashing bugs constantly,

There are several Game breaking bugs within the main mechanics that make it unplayable.

The building UI is a great idea, however the coding isn't right on it yet, Walls not being build, crashing when creating a big building, hearthlings not building a roof for your house for virtualy no reason. there are ways to make buildings with multiple walls, but most of them are tedious, requiring manual wall building, planning and erasing to get the building to work right, that is if you game doesnt crash on wall building or just make it so that you can not plan buildings anymore without save scumming.

Other than the bugs, there are features that are not present (some that they plan to add) that i belive are needed to round out the game and make it playable. I will list them here in hopes of Dev eyes and to establish discorse :D

-Stairs (they have already said its on its way, but without them it is hard to make multiple floors, ladders are visualy unappealing and dont support multiple hearthling travel)
-Manual Job Prioities (I wish that hauling wasn't a top prioities unless i set it as such)
-Underground Walls and rooms (Though possible, it is tedious, anothering on their to-do list)
-Better Mining Interface (Wish i could change all three tunnle dimentions)

Those are some basic things that i am sure they will add, but without them currently it makes this more of a proof of concept than a game. Here is a list of some otherthings that i belive will make up for the lack of depth

-Hearthling Personalities (Other than 3 stats, there is nothing that seperates one hearthling from another, making the game a bit shallow)
-Diffrent Starting Zones/Biomes/Varity (These are already on the To-Do list, right now there is almost no varity in starting zones.)


Really i had intentions for making this a long review and listing out everything i want to happen in this game in hopes of others seeing it and influencing the game, however it is just to soon to tell, they have so many good things planned for this including Multiplayer i only wish i didnt hear about this until it came out of early access, i yearn to play it everyday in its complete state.

So should you buy it? Yes.... Support these great devs.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

For all potential buyers:

This game is very fun and the art style is really awesome. It's like the best of everything from all the pseudo pixel-graphics titles being released so frequently now. I enjoyed playing this game, for an hour or so. The game has a lot of good concepts, but nothing seems even partially fleshed-out. I understand that it is an early access game, but still. Charging $20 for a a game that you can experience everything in within 4-5 hours of gameplay is criminal, in my opinion.

While I was watching some of the video reviews/let's plays, I saw that the characters don't have any sort of customization. They have no outfits, you can't assign them to a bed and decide where each one lives. This is fine with me, but I figured it was a trade-off for a more in-depth crafting system and/or building system. However, I was disappointed to find out that this was NOT the case. The crafting is very surface-level(and extremely annoying to level). The buildings have very little functionality other than to make your villagers do what they already do, better.

Overall, the experience was a bit underwhelming. It was too much of a simulator(and not even a good simulator at that) and not enough of an interactive city-builder, like I thought it would be. I actually bought this game because I played Cities: Skylines and felt that too much based on the simulation and less based around fun, but in the end, this game left with a similar feeling.

TLDR: Fun game. Cool art. No depth. Very little content.

If I could reccomend a couple things to the developers:
-Add more character customization. Instead of trying to build more into the job tree"
date:
give each person with that profession a separate talent tree that gives each character some identity and gives you a reason to have more than one of them other than just that their job isn't being taken care of.
-Add more functionality to buildings.
-Increase villager cap and allow for more space to build on and allow towns to be converted into cities.
-Add more tutorial information. Almost all of the stuff I had to learn how to do
recommended: was learned via videos. The tutorials taught me very little about how to play the game.\n\nP.S. I will be keeping an eye on this game with high hopes that it will be improved in future."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I don't think people understand the point of early access.
If you wan't a complete bug free game don't buy this.

Otherwise, If you like town builders... Well come on in, sit down, shut up and enjoy the ride. HOWEVER...

I have been with this game since it's first playable release... wait... sorry since it's second playable, you get it.
It is charming, and rewarding. You build up each and every buiding as well as Hearthlings (your villagers) for better or for worse. Each Hearthling can be given a job (Blacksmith, Carpenter, Hunter. ect. ect.) and based on some seemingly random stats, they will preform well or just level really slow.  When you have enough food/shelter/wealth - more villagers will start to join you (I swear they just  appear, no idea where they come from) Yes, they level to. They also die as well... which is why it is important to have someone with a sword handy at all times, otherwise the raiding goblins or night creatures... will end the town abruptly. Merchants, mining, farming all that good stuff with many many more features that will be implimented down the road thanks to their successful kickstarter.

Now enough fanboying... is this game really worth the purchase? yes.
Is it worth it in it's current stat? Sure, and I would recommend buying it LATER if you don't want to deal with small and some major bugs. But if you really understand what the concept of early access means and you aren't a child with mommy and daddy's credit card, then go ahead! Support the devs and then go to their forums to post any bugs you find! Then we can get through this a bit faster to release.

BTW to my friend's reading this... get this, there will be co-op and PvP later.

TL;DR
A great Village building game with mechanics similar to Minecraft, Banished and Dwarf Fortress. Well worth the money asked. Developers are HEAVILY involved in development and community relations, along with consistant and crisp graphics.The community of Stonehearth show how amazing this game is, and how much potential the developers have.

---------

Where do I start on this brilliant game? I've been watching this EA game since Alpha 2, and have finally decided to buy it. There are hundreds of pros and minimal cons. It is well worth the money asked for (you could wait until the summer sales heil gabeN) Or you can spend it right now!

Pros:

- The Developers
The developers are heavily community focused, implenting features people think would suit the game, as well as fixing game breaking bugs that are encountered. They do frequent updates (Around one every few weeks) and keep the community informed with Desktop Tuesdays" where they show off new features being implented

and don't randomly change with updates.

and help solve problems with bug fixes.

it gets a lot easier (my current "village" is on 40 hearthlings) and eventually you will end up with a small town.

- AI
The AI in this game can be

but eventually they get around to it.

CONCLUSION

I believe that this game has a HUGE potential

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I love games like Skyrim and World of Warcraft; Banished and SimCity. I love the medieval, high-fantasy settings of the first three, and the feeling of control in the last two. I have always been looking for a city-sim game that has a medieval look and feel, with an optional mixture of (high) fantasy. World of Warcraft was one of my first games. It certainly knocked the medieval requirement out of the park. Then, in 2011, I found Skyrim. Boy, did I love Skyrim. It was perfect, except.. it wasn't a city builder. I had no control of my environment in those other two games, I just had to play with what I had. So then I found Banished. It was perfect - medieval, city-builder.. but no real touch of (high) fantasy, and the only thing I had to worry about was resource management.

So a couple days ago I saw this game and fell in love with it the minute I saw the trailer video. It had everything I wanted - it was in a medieval setting, (high) fantasy, and it was a city-builder. Sure, it was in Alpha stage, but so what? I bought it and love it. The bugs and constant errors are annoying, but it is barely close to a final stage.

All I can say is, is that if you want a city-builder where you can pretty much control every aspect of your game, set in a high-fantasy medieval style, you'll love this. Some people might not like the voxel-based graphics, but it is worth it.

Now, I know I didn't delve into the actual game much, but if you're interested, when the game hits Beta or final release, you can check back for my full review. For now, if you want to help in the development of an amazing game, here it is.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I have preordered and bought into a variety of different early access games, and Stonehearth is the one of the first few where I feel like I got my money's worth, or at least, will. Though there is currently not much content, I have been quite content (see what I did there) with the game's current state and the direction it is going in. The game has a fantastic community and set of developers that are all intent on making this the best it can be.

Now, to the actual game:
It is a townbuilding game, like dwarf fortress or towns, with combat elements, random scenarios, specialized workers, mining mechanics, and, of course, housebuilding. I must also say that this game can be very relaxing thanks to its laid back theme and fitting music.

Because of it's early state, there are a variety of hilarious but also game breaking bugs. If you are easily frustrated by bugs and do not want to deal with bugs, I would recommend waiting until later to get the game.

I must also state that this game opened to steam early access on my birthday, so I am only slightly (completely) biased. Nonetheless, it looks like it will grow into a great game!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Best town game i've ever played. You build up a settlement and things attack you. Not to mention you have to keep up with how much food you are producing. (you can do much more, I'm just bad at explaining it.) As any game, its not without faults.

Here's a list of bugs Ive encountered while playing (THIS IS AN ALPHA THOUGH);
-villagers will begin to stand in one place when exiting a task to eat, often times they die of hunger. Ive only found one solution, mash the reset LUA button (F5)
-ALL your villagers begin to stand there and not do anything. Again, Mash F5 to solve. (Some times it works.)
-Footmen will continue to fight even when they are almost dead and you keep telling them to retreat.
-Villagers often will stop constructing a building and never finish it.
Most of these bugs force you to restart your village.

Also speaking of buildings, the current building tools are kind of limited as you can only make simple structures. The visuals are limited too, as you can only use  one or two material types and colors for each section (Except roads and floors). Also you cant make big stone castle walls, or add individual voxles to make detailed stuff.

Critisism aside, it's a wonderful game. But its not worth the 25 dollars.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nGreat game with sooo much potential. I still would recommend it, but I keep finding it nearly impossible to play. There are still so many bugs that need to be fixed. I love the game, but there are a few cons that make it unworth it in this stage of the game. You cannot make a single mistake with building, or you're screwed. You cannot destroy buildings. Why? I don't know, it's not implemented yet. Also, there are COUNTLESS bugs that I've encountered in game. Not just tiny bugs-the bugs were so bad I had to make a new game a few times. Still, great game with tons of potential. If they add in the ability to remove buildings, and fix the current bugs this game will be more than worth it!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Stonehearth is a (very) cute 3D version of town-building games like Dwarf Fortress or Gnomoria, where you must build a thriving settlement whilst fending off invasions and the like. Like Minecraft though, it has the option to play in peaceful mode for those who wish to just focus on the construction side of the game.

It should be emphasised that the game IS still in its alpha stages - that means there's only a limited amount of content in it at the moment. To be sure, there's plenty more to come, but this is definitely *early* access. That aside, it's definitely very enjoyable, and the building editor and the like allows for very complex structures to be built already, and a single game can happily last for a few hours before you've reduced the goblins & undead to little more than nuisances.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I would like to talk about the development cycle of this game being that it is in early access. I backed the game for $30 USD in April 2013 on Kickstarter, while the project timelines of the original crowd funding were not met, the transparency and progress on the game by the developers at Radiant Entertainment have always been thoroughly communicated.

Despite original project timelines not being met, the team has continued to grow and be staffed were needed, which in my opinion demonstrates sound management on the part of team. This is not a pick up and run with your money type of project. Updates are provided consistently and feedback is incorporated via the games blog, forum, trello roadmap, and Tom and Tony's tri-weekly twitch development streams.


Radiant Entertainment was founded by evo2k (the fighting game tournament) and shoryuken.com, founders Tony and Tom Cannon, who had years of working at vmware before venturing on this project. Tony Cannon also wrote netcode middleware GGPO, which was a turning point for online play in the fighting game genre.  I backed the game because of their history, these two have remained accountable and have earned the FGCs trust having been a cornerstone of the community.

To conclude, the development of this game two years after its successful crowdfunding campaign continues to demonstrate a level of accountability and trust that is among the best of early access games.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I've been playing the alpha since about 4 or 5.

In terms of the gameplay and potential....it's great. Basically what I had hoped Castle Story would be.  It has a long way to go, but it's organized and consistently improving. The Devs may not be the fastest, but they're /far/ from the slowest. Best of all, there's been an exponential curve in development and things have been picking up pace without major missteps.  The roadmap has held up and progress makes sense.

Dev isn't as fast as weekly content additions, but I have complete faith in the management of this team and the game seems deep and well-thought out...modding potential should be epic.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

TL;DR
1. Open and honest Dev team
2. Game is genuinly fun
3. Endless possibilities for its finished potential
4. Mod support is a thing

I have been a supporter of this game since the kickstarter campaign. It has gone through some very rough, very unpolished builds (seeing as this is currently in alpha 11), but the progress is constant. Each update comes in a timely manner and each one is noteworthy. The devs are open and honest about who is doing what and when things are likely to happen. If there is a setback they will tell you. This in of itself is a massive selling point for this game, just look at the mess that is Godus for a comparison. Regarding the game itself, its what I always wanted in a voxel style game; the freedom to create a city/kingdom from the ground up with my own unique band of citizens.

Building is fun; you can follow a few set blueprints or make your own from scratch. As the game develops you will eventually be able to make massive castles, but for the current version as of june 2015 multi-story buildings are the new thing.

Combat and resource gathering are about what you would expect, but agian this game is in its early stages and will become deeper as builds go on. Some of the stretch goals filled include elemental enemies and several magic using classes of hearthling. It is still in its early stages, but with the team behind it I am confident the potential will be realised.

Another commendation to the dev team behind this game is that from the outset they have encouraged modding. In the future I would not be surprised if the modding community embraced this game like they do bethesda games.

In closing, its a great game with a great team behind it and its only going to get better as it develops. Grab it now and become part of the community and help the devs out, because you will be hearing about this game in the future, and you will want it then anyway. Happy hearthing.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

A good rounded game that gets recommendation because of how good it will be when finished. You can easily sink 10 hours into the game before even beginning to reach the point when you'll run out of things to do. Right now the game has very frustrating bugs and gameplay progress issues that stunt long term gameplay. But i still think anyone interested in the game or the genre should buy it now. It is good enough to play and it's fun watching the game progress, with regular alpha updates and close communicastion between the devs and community. If you have any doubts just check out the subreddit r/stonehearth to see the very active community.

Considering there are less than 10 devs working on it the project is moving forward very fast to the point you can keep up with almost daily updates and watch the game progress. Join the movement now it is definitely worth it :)

reviewText:
Early Access Review

The game in it's current state is pretty glitchy but it has a dedicated and EXTREMELY involved staff. It's important to take into account this is an ALPHA version of the game which means they've been trying to get an MVP (minimum viable product) before they can take the time to apply all that finished-feeling polish. I'm extremely happy with where the game is at now and even more excited to see where it is going.

Just a small tidbit--I have the first version they ever released on my computer which was really just a glitchy demo that you could only sit and look at--it infact only opened up on one out of three computers. So amazing to see the product release by release! I recommend this game but only if you can look to the future :) Happy Stonehearthing

This game is amazing. I usually don't spend a lot of time on town managment games, but I was surprised at how addictive this game is. the vox style really gives the game some charm, every charecter is important in some way or form, and it's really noticable. doing simple things like building doors or making improvments to buildings feels really accomplishing, and the game, even in it's dull moments, still keeps my eye.
the onyl cons are: it runs on lua script, so once things start to get hectic, expect the game too go through some hiccups. there are a lot of bugs (early access, duh.) so don't expect the best user stability ever. the game also doesn't hold your hand, so you may have to go through some guides or figure out how things work on your own.

this game has a lot of promise, and I would love to see it's full form.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Stonehearth is a management sim where the goal is to create a thriving settlement. While it's a little feature-bare in it's current, in-development state, it's got a smart, minecrafty voxel system that lets you completely customize all elements of your settlement. The game also has decent performance and seems to be developed by a competent dev team. Which is, y'know, rare for a kickstartered early access game.

It's also built to support modding! That's always good.
voteText: 9 of 14 people (64%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Early Access Review

The dev team for this game are very good - the best ive seen for this genre of game. Development is promising, and the game itself is continually growing. I love this kind of game, however, in its current state, stonehearth is probably worth between $5 and $10.

The game is very easy - I've so far been able to repel every attack, destroy every enemy base etc with two soldiers (I might have been overdoing it adding the second soldier, too!).

Building is very bugged - I've had to cancel innumerable buildings as my villagers couldnt construct certain things or have gotten themselves stuck whilst trying. Being able to watch individual pieces on your building be placed by your citizens is cool but has lead to so many issues when actually performing this key functionality.

Progression is basic and unfulfilling - you are a fully self-sustaining within 1-3 days of in-game time. Sure, this might not be a problem, as the game may intend to focus on thriving rather than surviving. However, thriving is impossible as the game cannot seem to handle having >12 citizens (at such numbers, you will see a lot of idling, and citizens with professions flat refusing to do their allocated job whilst there are other things to do - and no, the citizen management screen does not resolve these issues).

Keep it on your watchlist, but unless you are looking for a very surface-level experience, steer clear until further down the development cycle.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

A very engaging city building title, Stonehearth offers many hours of fun. Being an early access title does mean that there will be issues, don't buy the game if this is a problem for you. If your are interested, but unsure just follow its development. That said the game is very fun. From my very first play through I played for 15 hours because I was so captivated by this game, bugs and all. The development team has done a very good job of weeding out said bugs. After my initial play, I too set the game aside with the intentions of returning once more progress was made with performance and gameplay. Well the devs came through! Many of the frustrating bugs I was dealing with have been fixed and on top of this many optimizations and features added. I am playing the current unstable branch (Alpah 14) at the time of writing this review. Irregardless, I was very happy to see that the team behind the game is very active unlike other titles I have bought.

The game is very simple: manage and provide for your hearthlings and watch them and the villiage grow. This simplicity is nice, but there is more depth to be found if you just look. Town building is very fun and very customizable. There is a set pallete of default building schematics at the start, but with a little imagination and creativity there is much you can do with the tool to design your own buildings. Also modding is being actively encouraged for the game by the devs.

Many of the negatives in some of the reviews have been addressed, atleast in the unstable branch
date: though that is not to stay new ones won't pop up. Again this is early access and with that in mind buyer beware. If you choose to buy this product look into it before doing so. In my short time so far with the game I have been impressed with the pace of development and the game itself. The forums for the game are active and the devs stream weekly on twitch, just check out their site.\n\nOverall, I am very happy with my purchase and look forward to he future of the game because it does look very bright. If you're on the fence, do your research, watch lets plays and see if this is really something for you. If you enjoy city building this game is very fun and relaxing, just give yourself time to get acquainted.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This is a highly enjoyable, in development, town building game. I have spent many hours building towns, learning the game, and enjoying the new game aspects they are adding from patch to patch as well as the bug fixes.

With all of the good things however, there are a few bad.
- The map generation takes quite a while per map roll (time consuming when looking for specific setups)
- Save files are not compatible with updates, meaning you will need to restart each time there's an update

These two things are not game breaking major, and they are wanting to implement the backward compatibility with save files, to prevent the need to constantly restart with updates, so it should no longer be a problem when they implement it.

This game offers unique textures and means to build your town as well as prevents the need to have them always be building whatever is placed, which helps prevent accidents. This lets you build roads, houses, and other structures the way you want it. Do you want a flat area? Doable, do you want a roof-less house? Doable. Multi-structured mansion? Doable. Throw your guys in a hole and never able to get out? This can also be done, and those who are fans of the Tycoon games, such as Rollercoaster Tycoon, you will be familiar with the ability to trap your visitors where they cannot leave, or killing them with rides. Make this your own experience with the city and enjoy yourself as you do so.

I will modify and go into more detail with this review as time goes on and as the game develops.

Update 11/27/2015:

This game has received quite a few updates since the original review. They have added the ability to create multi-tiered structures in the game, however this feature is a bit wonky and not 100% working in my opinion, as the settlers will often fail to build the bottom half of the house before the upper half or not build the building at all. They have also improved the errors that may happen in the game - if something were to bug out, it is no longer in a nasty developer box, but rather something a bit more user friendly to understand and depending on what fails, offers instructions on fixing the issue.

There are some present AI issues in the game that can make it a bit frustrating to have a large amount of tasks, I've been able to circumvent this issue in the developer versions of Alpha 13 - which is said to fix the AI issues in regards to building, etc, but may not be 100% done yet - by removing the request and redoing it or suspending/pausing the task then resuming it. Assuming there isnt still a ton of things already requested for them to do, they often figure out that it still needs to be completed. The game is still very much in a playable state and I still highly enjoy it and my original review still stands at this point in time. They are making progres toward finishing the game and adding features. Please note that at the time of this update, that saves are still not backward/forward compatible. And my original con of the map generation taking a lot of time still stands as well, but it feels a bit faster than it once was.

A few other major things they've added are a new style of settler and a new map biome type - the desert and raya's children. I've been able to play around with them in the developer build and its a very interesting change of pace to the normal gameplay that I had grown to love. This in combination with new professions and crafting systems in place permit for a more diverse and intricate creation system, making it feel like the crafters actually rely on each other to make the final product rather than it being a one man army. They have also vastly improved the game experience with making it run faster on my machine, and offering various options to help with slower/older machines as well as bug fixes. I haven't had massive bugs in regards to the UI or other pop-ups outside of one where I was clicking on buttons rapidly.

So let me mark off my cons at this point in time in regards to Alpha 12/Dev Alpha 13:
- Some AI issues in regards to tasks where they fail to complete (see above for my solution and some info)
- Map generation still takes too much time
- Save files are still not backward/forward compatible

This said, let me list some pros of this game thus far
- Multi-tiered structures
- Intricate crafting system
- Ability to trap your settlers
- Aggressive (normal surviving) & Peaceful mode (for building)
- Various travelling merchants

There's a lot more as well that I would list off but this review would end up to be too long.

Early Access Review

At the moment it shows a hell of a lot of promise, moving forward it's going to get even better! and THAT is what i'm looking forward to.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

=HEADS UP=
Early Access Review. The game is not finished yet but still worth the price.

=INFO ABOUT THE REVIEW=
1. This review is about my point of view and opinion. [If you disagree on a certain point or want to correct me: Be reasonable or i will ignore your comment.]

=REVIEW=
First i just have to say how happy i am that this game finally hits Steam. It was on Greenlight for a while and now finally it is on Steam. I have gotten the game before over kickstarter and i am just going to say that i usually dont get things over kickstarter. For me kickstarter was always a big risk and i never wanted to take that risk. But with this game it was completly different. The cute style and the idea behind it made it to something i just wanted to have.

The game overall is a normal little Building/Survival Sim. You have a certain amount of Settlers when you begin and start with nothing but a fire and a Townsflag. Over the time you build up your village and go up the steps towards a city. Mining, Smithing, Farming and even Fighting is already included in this and makes the whole experience already alot better than it looks on the pictures, even though they look quite good. (<3)

I cannot say how much i love this litte piece of art. This is one of those games where the devs really sit behind their game. And i am not saying this just like that. First before buying the game i had a chat with one of the Devs and i gotta say that i enjoyed it. After buying it i found a bug to submit and it got rid of right away with the next patch that came a few days after the report.

This game has a big future. Please whoever reads this: Be part of this future because i am sure that you will love it!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Stonehearth seems (even after about a year) very much still in the concept stage.  There's not much game here yet, but you can tell the devs are seriously devoted to making Stonehearth the best they can make it.  Even in this early stage you can tell it's the most charming, enjoyable 'concept' of a game out there (check my hours, and that's just through Steam).

The devs work closely with the community every step of the way and are immediately responsive to most all bug reports and suggestions.

The only caveat I can think of, is that it has been a long, long time getting to even where it is now, and it still has a long long way to go.  I do think it will get there and I have the utmost faith in the devs, but don't expect it in a mere few months.

Your money invested here is not to have a fleshed out playable game today or tomorrow, but to help ensure the devs can make Stonehearth all it can be.  You won't have a game you can play day in and day out... just yet.. but it will happen and it will be wonderful.

Edit:  I've changed my recommendation to NO for the time being.  There's just too little game here for the high price they're charging.  That high price was fine for kickstarter where you were investing, but now they're selling it on Steam and there just isn't much of a game here for that kind of money.  I also have concerns about how long development is taking.  Don't forget, this game has been in development for two years before it hit Steam early access. Over two years now and frankly, not much has happened for such a long dev cycle.  I honestly think the devs have gotten in over their heads and don't quite know how to dig themselves out of this hole.

I'll happily change to Recommended when I see this game kick into high gear, but for now, it's 'wait and see'.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Alright, I've played this game far longer than steam is showing, because I played it hours before I had it on steam at all.
Also, I've been following this game for around two years now, and I think you can call me a fanboy. So is this review going to be neutral? No, definitely not! I love this game, and I probably oversee a lot of bugs. But at least it has a reason why I'm calling myself a fanboy.

Two years ago, I think summer 2013, I've noticed a game called Stonehearth. A german video game magazine called gamestar" reviewed it. A sandbox town building game in a voxel based world? Call me childish
date: but I loved to build huge lego forts so this game was bought instantly using the humble store for a much higher price than it's here on Early Access. I do not regret a single penny. Back then
recommended: the game was nearly unplayable. You enjoyed the concept for 15 minutes
hoursPlayed: but no longer. But
voteText: and this is at least for me one of the only criterion of an Early Access game
helpfulPercent: the developers were active. They posted news frequently and from time to time a new update was released. Not that often like - let's say Space Engineers - but frequent and huge updates.\nNow we have come to the point where I can honestly say that you can play it for some hours - if you are aware of some gamebreaking bugs. For example: Your workers need to eat

votesFunny:
to get an idea of what the game is going to be and to have a nice game for a cheap price when it's released!

Now to the game itself:
Imagine you play Minecraft. But not as a player

reviewText:
Early Access Review

*Posted December 31 2015*



Ok, so as you can see this game is a early access games with a few bugs that I have come across so, today I will give you a list of some of the Pros and Cons of the game.


Pros-
Fun
Great design
Combat
Farming
OK graphics
Regular updates (about once a month)



Cons-
Combat is mostly broken
Way to many challenges such as Goblins which spawn like every 5-10 minutes which I think is un-fair
Lots of bugs
I would of really liked to build my own houses but most of the time it breaks and during the design if you screw one thing up you have to start it over again



So in conclusion I would recomend this game to other but not if your looking for a real time waster you will most likely spend a few hours of the game then get bored so until the game is complete I would recomend it unless you want to build your own houses.

Early Access Review

Awesome concept. Simple, yet complex enough to keep you interested. A lot of potential for the future, where Campaigns, Mulitplayer (Co-op and PvP) is planned. There is also mod support, and already a few mods out there.

And the best part is the fact that this is a EA game where updates are VERY frequent. Not just bug fixes and performance updates, but actual content.

Early Access Review

I just played the latest update (alpha 12) and as far as i can tell not much has changed, a few new items here, lots of bugs and here, ui problems there.

I like the game and it seems like it's progressing, the learning curve isn't steep. but it's in early alpha so there isn't much content and also bugs are to be expected.

I think it's better to wait until the game is done to get the full value(or buy Early Access to support devs but don't complain if it has game breaking bugs just post the bugs on the designated forum).

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Stonehearth, is a stoned survival and exploration game in a epic fantasy world, where you settle a town of hearthlings while defending agens invaders.

The games layout, animations and sounds are really great, specially the way we can build the houses and duplicate our buildings on the ground, for each pieace. We can design everything from: Window, floor, door, roof, flags, fire, beds, and more. On the path while playing the game, people will visit your town and you can sell / buy upgrades. The atmosphere of the game is really nice, and you getting hooked really quickly.

Be aware! They need some fixes aswell. Please keep in mind that this is Early access, and it's not finished. Check out my and others suggestions here: http://steamcommunity.com/app/253250/discussions/0/594821545179359856/

Don't be a fool and think it's not worth it because of the missing features or sometime crashes with 5.273 error messages.

If you search a relaxing and interesting stone, exploration and survival game in a fantasy world with invaders either in creative or survival mode, then this game is for you.

Here is some old gameplay footage from june:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=jvsldnDo158&index=1&list=PLxDx_O1l8oBtKptsAJew1pUOgkfYyOYh6

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Great game. I recommend this game to anyone who likes creative sandbox games and even the casual RTS gamer.

Its alpha, so obviously there are bugs being worked out. None of the bugs are game breaking and most can be fixed by simply saving and reloading. They also make console commands available as a work around for some bugs.

Its great for releasing your inner creativity. Think of building something in Minecraft or Terraria, except not having to place each individual piece yourself. You design the building in a design mode and when you are finished editing you hit the build button and then your people do all the work. This makes building larger more complex structures much less time consuming. There is a building template saving feature so that your creations can be saved for other games. If you make a massive structure simply save it and you can copy paste it to another world, all you need is the materials.

The combat is fun as well, but can be turned off if you wish to play in the sandbox mode. Being able to assign units to gaurd (footmen) roles and creating/finding better gear for them to use. The game gets progressively harder to a point then seems to level out and nothing can defeat your footmen. But again its alpha and the combat was only just released so its basically there to be tested and tuned.

Multiplayer has not been implemented yet but it is planned in the future and I believe that this game has some great potential at some fun multiplayer gameplay.
voteText: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Only five hours in but I'm having a TON of fun, and it's only in alpha.

THE QUICK VERSION: Do you like Gnomoria (or Dwarf Fortress)? Do you like Minecraft? If you answered yes" to either of these
date: you'll most likely enjoy this game. If you answered "yes" to both
recommended:
you'll DEFINITELY enjoy this game.

THINGS TO LIKE:

+ The building system is the most robust of any citybuilder I've seen to date. You not only get to lay out buildings for your Hearthlings to construct (very intuitively
hoursPlayed: in my experience!) but you get to place furniture within and without at your whim. There's already a great deal of different types of furniture and decor your Hearthings can craft.\n\n+ The music is excellent. It's rich and well composed
voteText: and it gives the game a very quaint feel.\n\n+ Game generation is simple but fun and really makes you feel like you're having an impact on your game before it even starts. You roll a set of Hearthlings
helpfulPercent: each with their own stats
votesHelpful: and can even name them. You also get an amount of gold to spend on a selection of items to start yourself off with. You select your options in storybook form when the game asks you to pick between two types of Hearthlings (one medieval-ish group and one nomadic
votesTotal: desert-like group)
votesFunny: two types of biomes (temperate or desert)
commentsCount: and two types of game (either you can be raided by enemies or you can't). Then your map is generated and you select where on that map you want to settle. Each region has access to different resources.\n\n+ Trade events. Just about every day
column16: a trader will come by offering different deals. You can buy or sell certain goods from some
column17: some will ask you to make them x number of items then come back after a set amount of time to trade you something agreed upon for them... It keeps things fresh and gives you new ways to get resources you maybe don't have access to based on where you settled.\n\n+ Hearthling jobs. There are several different jobs in the game and they all feel useful. Every Hearthling starts off as a basic laborer
column18: who can only gather resources
column19: haul them
column20: or build. With items (most of which are constructed by the various crafting jobs)
column21: you can promote a hearthling to any number of other jobs such as Farmer
column22: Carpenter
column23: Tailor or Trapper. Every job has levels that increase as your Hearthling performs that job and gains experience. At each tier
column24: a new ability is unlocked. These range from increased speed to the ability to randomly create high-quality furniture that takes on a finer appearance than the base item being crafted. Many jobs are also laid out in a tree wherein you must have a Hearthling of level x in one job to promote to another. For example
column25:
Cook requires Farmer at level 3.

+ The ability to save your building designs for easy placement later.

THINGS THAT NEED WORK:

- Currently it's very difficult (possible though!) to build a second floor that functions. I'm sure this will be ironed out as the game plods along in development
column26: though.\n\n- A few of the job abilities aren't implemented yet
column27: but this will definitely be remedied later just on nature of the status being "not implemented".\n\n- You get occasional errors when trying to do things
column28: pretty much always in regards to building. They haven't crashed the game for me
column29: it's basically just the game telling me the engine didn't understand what I was trying to do.\n\n- Sometimes the building bugs a bit
column30: but all that generally means is that you have to cancel building and start designing from the start again. Bit of a pain
column33:
and this is sure to be ironed out in the long term.

FINAL VERDICT:

It's already an incredibly addictive game for me. In its current state
column34: I'd rate the game a solid 7.5/10. It has the potential to be at LEAST a 9. If for whatever reason you trust my opinion
column35: I'd tell you this game is worth the buy right now. It's one of the sharpest alpha states I've ever seen for a game and there's already so much to enjoy and lose hours in. Five hours in
column36: I've only scratched the surface of jobs and the like and I'm still going strong. I can see myself easily logging over 100 hours in this thing."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Stonehearth is a very promising village/town builder! I'm very glad to have helped kickstart it.

The developers push out updates and improvents frequently.

Anyone who is a fan of Dwarf Fortress and DF-lite games (Gnomoria, Spacebase DF-9) will enjoy Stonehearth.

Sure, as of this post, it has its share of issues:
Bugs (with the occasional crash to desktop)
Waning performance (CPU and AI decision-making) over time (needing the occasional save-then-reload to refresh)
Some not-yet-implemented UI functionality and UX flow that can make building clunky and unforgiving
That said, Stonehearth not only shows improvement after every update, but it's also already quite fun to play!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Stonehearth (Alpha 10) can be best described as a pretty, easy to use, and lightweight Dwarf Fortress for the masses. None of what I just said should be taken negatively. It's a great concept. I absolutely can't wait for final release, because I'm convinced the devs are going to make it happen and hit a home run in the process.

As the game stands, it wasn't until the latest Alpha release (alpha 10) a couple of weeks ago that Stonehearth actually started to feel like a game. So giving a fair review is hard to do. Let's just jump to whether or not you should buy in to the game as it is now.

If you are an indie supporter who likes to see a game evolve and support a project early on, then yes, it's a great buy. Also if you are content with what amounts to a sandbox that is still very much a trial run of the features in the design doc but are OK with may features still outstanding, then certainly dive in while the water is relatively clean. The game is being made by great team that stays heavily connected to the community.

If you are looking for a game that is near feature complete with only minor bugs, then perhaps it's worth waiting. If I had to guess, Stonehearth is at least a year away from being ready for final release; so if you don't have the patience to wait until the features you want are in the game, then you may want to wait. Perhaps the Early Access money from Steam will afford a larger team and speed up the development...

In the end, be sure and check out the games website and watch some YouTube videos to help with your decision.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This is one of those original games that you know can really go so far with the right amount of love and development. And for the few months I had this game before it hit steam early acess the devs have really proven that they are dedicated and willing to release frequent updates, and as important: fix bugs!
Sure the game isn't complete and they are still adding more features, but already this is an awesome and open world, a city-sim with the micromanegement that an rts player would love.
Another thing that really strikes me as impressive, and eleviates most of my concerns regarding the fact that it lacks content in some areas is their openess to the community. These guys are really awesome and open about their plans, have frequent dev streams and will tell you exactly what they are working on. In my opinion this is truly early access done right, and thats why this game is much more than some buggy early access scam.
Definitely recommended.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

One of the backers, here. Game is still in early alpha, but, by this point, has a fair amount to offer. Multiple-story buildings, combat, raids and counter-raids, and some nasties that come say hi at night. Great town simulation game with fun RPG elements.

At the moment it's still short of what it wants to be, but with the progress the devs have made in the transparency in their progression, I doubt it will be long before you can play with your buddies and experience the other classes and goodies the game will offer.

It's a game I've had fun coming back to nearly every update, and one that I eagerly await release of. Keep up the good work, Radiant!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I've been excited for Stonehearth since the Kickstarter which I happily contributed to. I saw a team of people who were passionate about delivering the product they envisioned instead of a watered down version.

Two years later I'm happy to see that I wasn't wrong. The development team is very transparent, honest, and are not willing to give up on their vision like so many other games have. Unfortunately, that means that some things take longer to do and have more bugs because the implementations are more complex. I've watched and played the alphas, though, and I've seen fantastic and surprisingly rapid growth so I'm optimistic about where this game will be when it's finally complete.

Worth the price, but please remember this is alpha-quality software so there may be some frustrations. Alpha 10 is pretty stable but if you'd like to avoid some of the game-breaking issues that can sometimes pop up I would wait a few more versions or even until Beta when the real bug fixing kicks in.
voteText: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful 1 person found this review funny

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I first played Stonehearth back in alpha, and thought that it wasn't as much of a deal back then, but was largely intrigued by the well-rounded corners the developers mainly got around to. It was appealing and affectionate; something the current game libraries didn't offer a lot of. Granted, I took the jump into the warm water and it was mainly filled with bugs. Like a LOT of bugs.

Thankfully, many patches and versions later, we get to play this much more toned, much more carved game that really resonated with me in a lot of ways. This game has the appealing factor of Minecraft, the RTS-feel of Tropico meets Banished and forms a bond that revolves around both styles really well. You could say it's like an RTS/RPG but that is also missing the mark.

Granted, it is still in alpha, but damn do I love this game. After getting back in a month later, many problems were fixed, while there were problems lingering. Still, this game is fantastically crafted and makes you feel as if while creating your little village, that you're connected with your Hearthlings, a.k.a your units/villagers. What's interesting is that there is an objective, and not mindless building nor reacting to an enemy assault from orcs. This game makes you feel as if you're working together with your Hearthlings, and it is damn awesome.

The soundtrack is fantastic, there are a TON to do and TONS MORE coming! This game has potential, and also if there are known bugs DO let the developers know. Let's make this gem of a game shine. Congrats to Team Radiant! This is one hell of a fantastic game!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Stonehearth is a sandbox-rpg town builder with a lot of heart. I’ve been playing the game since Alpha 3 and it’s the only early development game i’ve had zero regrets about purchasing.

Community And Developers:
The Stonehearth Discourse is full of awesome and helpful people. It’s a very good grouping of gamers really trying to help each other out. Friendliest discourse on the net.

The developers at Stonehearth truly are one of a kind. They continue to be very open about what is happening with the game and participate in discussion on the discourse. They REALLY do listen to feedback, i've seen it happen multiple times where the community will spotlight a great idea and it makes it into the game.

But the main thing is… they stream THREE times a week on Twitch, Tuesday, Wednesday, Thursday. Two design live streams and one coding stream. Tony and Tom answer questions accept feedback with the best of them.

On top of this, they do a development blog once a week, sometimes twice.

Alphas get pumped out one every 6-8 weeks on average. In between that, they update the unstable branch that allows you to play test the upcoming features, and those come pretty quickly after main Alpha releases.

Gameplay:
The game plays great You set up the tasks and then can kick back and watch as your Hearthlings go to work. Farmers need to direction as they constantly plant, harvest, and replant food. The trapper will automatically head to the trapping zones you set up, survey the lands, and place out traps to catch small game. And one of my favorites... footman will patrol along your roads and stockpiles, wary for danger.

With the Dungeon Master Ai system, it spawns events and campaigns (I won't spoil what) that come to mess with your village. In some cases, you are given multiple options on how to handle it.

Overall:
I think the Devs said it best

It’s important to understand that Stonehearth isn’t finished yet. Not by a long shot. But Stonehearth
hoursPlayed:
robust gameplay and plenty to do and explore."


Pros:
Community ++
Developers ++
Development Speed +
Developer Openness and Communication ++
Plays smooth
Just good Fun!
Oozes Character and cuteness
Dungeon Master System AI

Cons:
Buggy! (it’s alpha)
Price is in the mid-high range for EA
voteText: but seems right for the final game.\nGame Still has a long ways to go to be fully featured"

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Stonehearth (Alpha 10) can be best described as a pretty, easy to use, and lightweight Dwarf Fortress for the masses. None of what I just said should be taken negatively. It's a great concept. I absolutely can't wait for final release, because I'm convinced the devs are going to make it happen and hit a home run in the process.

As the game stands, it wasn't until the latest Alpha release (alpha 10) a couple of weeks ago that Stonehearth actually started to feel like a game. So giving a fair review is hard to do. Let's just jump to whether or not you should buy in to the game as it is now.

If you are an indie supporter who likes to see a game evolve and support a project early on, then yes, it's a great buy. Also if you are content with what amounts to a sandbox that is still very much a trial run of the features in the design doc but are OK with may features still outstanding, then certainly dive in while the water is relatively clean. The game is being made by great team that stays heavily connected to the community.

If you are looking for a game that is near feature complete with only minor bugs, then perhaps it's worth waiting. If I had to guess, Stonehearth is at least a year away from being ready for final release; so if you don't have the patience to wait until the features you want are in the game, then you may want to wait. Perhaps the Early Access money from Steam will afford a larger team and speed up the development...

In the end, be sure and check out the games website and watch some YouTube videos to help with your decision.

Early Access Review

This is one of those original games that you know can really go so far with the right amount of love and development. And for the few months I had this game before it hit steam early acess the devs have really proven that they are dedicated and willing to release frequent updates, and as important: fix bugs!
Sure the game isn't complete and they are still adding more features, but already this is an awesome and open world, a city-sim with the micromanegement that an rts player would love.
Another thing that really strikes me as impressive, and eleviates most of my concerns regarding the fact that it lacks content in some areas is their openess to the community. These guys are really awesome and open about their plans, have frequent dev streams and will tell you exactly what they are working on. In my opinion this is truly early access done right, and thats why this game is much more than some buggy early access scam.
Definitely recommended.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

One of the backers, here. Game is still in early alpha, but, by this point, has a fair amount to offer. Multiple-story buildings, combat, raids and counter-raids, and some nasties that come say hi at night. Great town simulation game with fun RPG elements.

At the moment it's still short of what it wants to be, but with the progress the devs have made in the transparency in their progression, I doubt it will be long before you can play with your buddies and experience the other classes and goodies the game will offer.

It's a game I've had fun coming back to nearly every update, and one that I eagerly await release of. Keep up the good work, Radiant!

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nThe price of this game shouldn't be $27.99 right now. To me, i'd played at least 2 other early access games that should have been 27.99 at start but instead was at least half of their selling price. The game is still fun and simple in a way it is a replica to minecraft and terraria, just not in first person or third person mode and is in a creators point of view ( not an author either since there is no story or plot involved) which made the game unique yet full of potential to upcoming changes. Basically, you can not move your units like you would when you play starcraft. They have their own sort of ai intelligence but you you can control em by commanding the things they can do like harvesting, building and etc. This is the reason why the game got soo positive beside cartooony artwork. The art and the design iteself is amazing but is definitly lacking way too much content in the meantime and has alot of bugs that become annoying to bypass after playing for 9 hours. The bugs arn't too serious but there's way to bypass them where you have to think outside the box in order to make the game playable as much as possible until when i wanted to load back my game, everything froze. The game is running fine including the music but everything that once full of life just stopped as if i had paused the game, which i didn't. There is alot of potential in this game, the game is only worth reviewing once more when it is fully out since they going to add multiplayer in and other features but if it gets to the point where it is not going to be those pay to win games. Only then i would see this game is still worth buying at $27.99-$49.99. The gameplay is very slow. SO if you're a type of person whose into simulation where not alot of things are going on, you will enjoy playing this game alot. It's like sims but you get to control the lives of the community than one person/ family. Most importantly, they should add more features if they arn't ready for contents like horses , archers, traps for enemies and etc vs. social interaction between the npcs (more advanced) instead of villagers being a coward  when they see any monsters cause eevryone is different. More customization for your character and npcs, like names, clothes, and etc. Their background story randomly generated would be awesome as well. It's worth watching people playing based on their creativity in making towns, kingdoms, cityscapes in a sandbox but it is defnitly not worth buying if you're those people who love intense, fast-paced environment.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Stonehearth is a very promising village/town builder! I'm very glad to have helped kickstart it.

The developers push out updates and improvents frequently.

Anyone who is a fan of Dwarf Fortress and DF-lite games (Gnomoria, Spacebase DF-9) will enjoy Stonehearth.

Sure, as of this post, it has its share of issues:
Bugs (with the occasional crash to desktop)
Waning performance (CPU and AI decision-making) over time (needing the occasional save-then-reload to refresh)
Some not-yet-implemented UI functionality and UX flow that can make building clunky and unforgiving
That said, Stonehearth not only shows improvement after every update, but it's also already quite fun to play!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I spent a small amount of time playing Stonehearth and with a brief summary can say this game is the future Gnomoria. It does everything a simulation civilization survival game should do. It has a bit of leveling up, looser micromanaging, customizing buildings, unlockable classes, and a better feel of the open world. When your Hearthlings get hungry and you ask them to harvest berries, they don't starve themselves on a job and wait for another job class to go do it, they stop everything and grab some wild berries. I will say Gnomoria has a leg up in terms of making your own classes and uniforms but I'm sure as this game progresses it'll have the same options if not more that Gnomoria had to offer. The music isn't half bad and is soft however it does keep reminding me of the little mermaid...

It is an EA and like all EA's theres errors but to have the game working on the day of steam release is a first +1 for its score, having a few options +1, having a save and load function +1, having most of the key features working in-game +1, having a balanced and playable gameplay +1, and finally I only encountered 2 bugs that have already been reported the headless bug and the red error box when making a custom house, neither were game breaking or that annoying due to being able to move the red box and the heads stay on if you zoom out. So for me a personal +1. I also want to wrap up by saying a huge HUGE THANK YOU to both the greenlight voters and the developers! The developers I thank you for stepping up to the plate WHEN YOU FELT READY, taking time to process your game and release it almost stable is a huge hat off to you (even though I don't wear hats).

The price is a bit of a shock to those with lower paychecks and what with the economy the way it is don't be to embarrassed to wait. This game has great delivery, great promise, and a great dev team so far from what I can tell at least. I'll wrap this up by saying Steam needs more Indie dev teams like this who wait until the game is stable and has most of its key elements already in game.

Right now there is too many bugs which is obviously going to be in the game due to it being an EA game. Once it is out of EA then i will recommend getting it. At this moment, I cant recommend.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I've been following this game since its Kickstarter debut. I have to say I am super impressed with the teams commitment to listening to the community and including us in the process. Every week there are multiple updates on the forum regarding the new alpha releases or other changes.

This is definitely a game still in development. If you purchase do not get too attached to any build because upon the next alpha release you will be starting over again and systems may change. Things crash and odd bugs will happen - but that's the definition of an alpha.

This game has huge potential and even though its only an alpha there is enough content to keep me procrastinating for hours on building my town. I just love it - for me its the next best thing since minecraft - or it will be!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I love it!
Though it still is in  alpha  and theres yet much missing and to be added, the whole concept and gameplay is good.
Quite good. I love RTS games and iv allways wanted/missed a city building game with a medeival/fantasy theme and now here it is. It gave me a realy good first impression; artstyle of the game is wonderfull, the mechanics for now is also nice though it still needs some work, most features are great. I have much hope and belief that this game will become a great.

Some important notes:

- Graphics/artstyle is fine and refreshing, it resembles minecraft obviously but much more clean and polished so i wouldnt be worrying about the graphical look if you're that type of guy. Artstyle, by the look of the concept art there is a lot more cool stuff to come and im eager to test out the upcoming updates.

- Mechanics in the game are okay: Not bad or to unique which fits perfectly, it may be a bit tricky to learn the basics in the game without a tutorial or guidline in-game but its workable.
I love the ability to  customize the buildings and housings entirely from scratch , this was a suckerpunch for me and sold me. You can then later on decide what the building should be used for and as (example blacksmith, barracks, tavern etc.. etc). You can also customize the interior as in rugs, curtains, style of furniture and so on.
I find it amusing that this is a RTS with such neat customization features, it realy makes it fun for people who appriciate city building games down to the tiniest details.

Classes of the workers so far is well made, cant complain besides the lack of a ranged/archer class but that will be added later and many more other classes as well have they noted.

- Lore/Story, not much to say about that now in the Alpha but after what iv read it looks promising for what is to come. There are some quests with the goblins which are pretty neat but there isnt much else to say about that.

-Upcoming features; Multiplayer, coop will be fun i believe. Im looking more forward to the concept of coop in a city building game, im interested to see if they will make it so players can build one big city together and manage it as well, if so that would be awesome.


The negative about the game?

Its an alpha, bugs and glitches are to be expected. Only major flaw i find in the current alpha is that the game will lag/crash when you pass the villager/worker limit of 25 +. Besides that i cant find much flaw in it knowing a lot more concent will be added and fixed.



I strongly recommend the game 8/10, its a neat mix of RTS and RPG . Its like a small mix of Warcraft 3, Banished, Age of Mythology and Age of Empires.   40 hours in  and its just a alpha! Realy entertaining so far, and i look forward to what the developers will do with the game.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Today I will review Stonehearth.

This is an excellent Early Access Game that never fails to deliver every month it has a new alpha with many new features that change the game in a big way i think this game has alot of promise and the devs are always responding to feedback to make it better.

Stonehearth is a survival town building game with monsters and goblins constantly invading your town. It has solid building mechanics where you can build what ever you want with constant improvement although the bigger you go the more bugs you will encounter.

Secondly Stonehearth requires you to raise animals farms hunting cooking and mining in order to get the resources you need to help your town grow with many thing to craft cook and farm. The graphics are also very calm and pleasent with its voxelated world.

As of its new update there is a new playable kingdom biomes and LESS BUGS YAY!

The Bad:

Combat is far too easy sometimes i would like to see reival factions and kingdoms
More classes and things to craft... Never can have enough
BUGS BUGS BUGS GRRRR!

Thats it for bad things...

I cannot stress enoough on how good this game is it is simpily wonderful and is constantly getting better i would highly recommend you go and buy it now go go go!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I really do love the concept of this game.  The game has settlers left in the wilds to fend for themselves.  They slowly start to learn the basics to create their own city and a home for themeslves.

At this point, though, the game is not ready.  The bugs are hard to get over and the game has not been updated to handle 'end of game' content or what happens when you level.  I build a place for everyone to sleep, to eat and then I'm pretty much done.  I have everyone collect resources, but really this only happens sometimes.  My blacksmith or Mason level up to create new things for my settlement, but I'm unable to impliment them, I don't see a reason to use them, and I can't make my own due to glitches.

Now I don't want you to stray from the basic game.  Despite this all, as I frist stated, the game is headed in the right direction and I hope it continues that way.  If the developer can pull this all together I think we'll have a huge hit on our hands a game I won't be able to stop playing.

I do think the game is worth a try!  Watch out for the goblins!

So if you're into city builders, RPG's and active developers this game is for you.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

When I first bought this game I was upset at all of the constant game breaking bugs and instability. Constant content updates but no bug updates. (Early access rules clearly state the game must be playable through all stages of development) but as time went on the game's bugs were slowly pushed back, some weren't completely removed. Of course this is all expected of a early access game, however it was pretty bad.

Every now and then I come back to stonehearth and see the amazing improvements they have made. Since the game is early access it has its limitations, one of the major ones was the idle bug" which caused all of the villagers to permanently cease any and all activity and the save would be permanently broken. However they added a cap of 24 villagers now and optimized the game. So now we are limited to just 24 villagers.


All in all I love the game and love the spirit of stonehearth 8/10"

reviewText:
Early Access Review

It has the potential to become something great, but i feel the game is a little disorganized in gameplay.  Theres some micromanagement needed to produce goods, and I feel the hearthlings needs better AI to collect reasources and items that are just lying on the ground. Not only that I have trouble crafting because i don't have an instant idea of what reasources i already have and and what i need to craft new items and even build buildings.


I guess what I think the game really needs right now is for the hearthlings to become more intilligent and autnomous so that they're always doing something productive other than restocking the stockpile when i'm not giving orders.


These are all things i think should be dealt with as the game updates. Quite frankly i'm impressed that the game is set to continue running depsite all the erros and bugs that pop up which is of course a clear indication that the game still needs some polishing. But I am sure that once this game is eventually completed it should become something very fun.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I have been playing Stonehearth since very early access (Alpha 2 roughly). It has been a true joy to watch this game grow from the core mechanics into what it is now.

I will not say that the game is complete or necessarily good. There is a lot of content still to implement, features to add and polish to be put in, but as it stands, Stonehearth is playable and offers several hours worth of gameplay in its current state. Given the price of almost $30, I would not recommend buying it unless you want into the early access system. The game does not, currently, have $30 worth of content.

In spite of that, I do strongly recommend this game, both now and most likely when it leaves early access. The team is dedicated and communication is open and transparent. The game's modability is very good and new content rolls out every few weeks, showing that development is definitely active and lively.

9/10, Really fun but it's still in alpha and could use a little work.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This will be simple and to the point based on my findings with this game 11/10/2015

-This is for you if you like
Casual games
Easy Combat
Easy Survival
Difficult Building Tools (I only say this because it took me a bit to find that the walls go around the foundation not on it)

-This is not for you if you like
A challage ( I fell asleep for 4hrs and my people survived on there own )
To make this a little shorter lets just say at this point everything from the combat to survival is easy mode
I dont even know if your people require food its so easy to get

-3 warriors (Wooden Sword and Shield) 2 farmers
grats you now have a stable civ ready for anything

-Summary
The hardest part of this game is getting the off the wall requirements for your next villager Its so easy at this time its borring

-Ending note Steam wont let me refund because I fell asleep so im going to try to get my money out of it and try to see if I can make this game a challange will change this if I can find a way to make this challangeing

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nIf you quite like sandbox games where you build and mine, this is not the game for you. I am completely aware that this game is in early access and that content has not all been fixed in place, however there are other games out there that do the same thing, but better and cheaper. The price tag for this game is steep, $25. I managed to play 8 hours, while most of that was just waiting for the little villagers to complete their tasks, and the game was pretty much over. This game is worth $5. If you are looking for an interesting game to play that are similar I would reccommend Gnomoria, Craft The World, and Banished. Totally worth the money. You can get both Gnomoria and Banished for $27. Go that route, I should have listened to Tom.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

It's solid fun.

What to expect:

-Little Village game
-Feel like mincraft
-command little villagers to farm, take on jobs, be soldiers, craftsmen, etc.
-battle other villages, encounter them, encounter goblin villages, pay tithe or go to war? Engage in a little bit of diplomacy
-engage in trading


Overall relaxing, fun, enjoyable. I think it has the right balance between warfare, crafting, diplomacy, customization of buildings objects.


HOWEVER, this game is in early access. I dont feel it's complete enough to warrant buying.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

TL;DR
Too exensive for so little content.


In itself the game has a lot of potential. Basically it is a RTS Minecraft more or less. You decide what your villagers build, what furniture or weapons they craft etc etc.

Sadly, the content so far is very limited. And it does not feel like there is any progress in this regard.
After the first few nights it feels like there is nothing left to do. You have accomodation, a few farms and traps and a small military squad to fend off invaders.
From that point onward it is literally just wathing your villagers eat and sleep.

If the devs would add more content this would definitely be a recommendation. But in its current state the game is way too expensive.

Early Access Review

Stonehearth is a overall great game, with lots of potential to make it better. The only problem I have encountered is that it some computers can't handle it and will lag out and possibly lose your world. ITS A GAME. Here are the pros and cons, pros run well (most of the time) the animals and people are cute looking, you can get a lot of people(I got at least twenty eight in the alpha) there is a lot of exploring and the goblins look ridiculous. Cons (everyone likes these) :steammocking: after your town gets bigger it starts lagging more, the goblin raids can be devastating and I think there needs to be more weapons. Overall a good game that I highly recommend to everyone. :steamhappy:

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nSince alpha 16, this game is definitely one of the best to get on Steam. It already had a lot of special features before, giving you the feeling to play Minecraft inside visuals that reminded me of Final Fantasy tactics... and not only the beautiful Indie graphic style, but the whole job system reminded me that game I loved. And then the combat update (alpha 16) just bring the game to a whole new level. There's a story line, a scenario where clans of orcs and goblins will come and try to take you out after offering you to pay tribute or be killed. You have the choice. This is an open-world-Indie-RPG-sandbox-Minecraft-style-realtime-strategy game that is definitely worth trying ! You can choose to explore and fight in almost non-stop action or choose the peaceful mode or just hit the pause button while you design slowly a whole civilization block by block with all the details you want to add. You can dig your hole through the mountain and keep hiding there or just build the biggest castle in the middle of a big lake with bridges and secret tunels... it's all up to you! Alpha 16 is now super stable and incredibly polished for an alpha release. Stop what you're doing and just try this game now ! ;)

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nThe devs put their heart and souls into this game, and it shows! They're always adding in new and intersesting features and complete a new alpha release every month or so. It's nice to have a game where you can build whatever you want while defending it from the various and expanding array of monsters. I love the RPG elements of needing a previous class in order to advance further. Or a different class is needed to craft the necessary tool to level up a hearthling. Alpha games have lots of bugs you say? Fear not! Many of the game-breaking bugs or annoying bugs that I experienced when I first bought this game are all gone or at least are being addressed and steps are being made toward fixing it.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Despite being in Alpha, this game has already come a long way.

I've been playing Stonehearth for quite a long time now and it has never ceased to please me. The game's developers are active and it gets updated frequently, which is always great to see. Many things inside the game are customisable, such as the design of your buildings.

My ONLY grudge are the bugs and errors that sometimes occur, but being in Alpha this is fully understandable, and the devs really seem to pay attention to their community and knuckle down those pesky things.

They have a great concept and I can only see it getting better from here. If you're a fan of the town-building/defense genre with money to spend, look no further than Stonehearth.
